entry.title: Pre-Release Chapters
entry.content:
One of the problems of having a weekly release schedule for The Odessia is that it gives me little time to solicit feedback and amend the text before publication.  I don't want to delay publishing a chapter, but making numerous changes to the chapter after it's posted is undesirable for many reasons -- most people want to read the final draft, it could wreak havoc with people's feed readers, etc.

Because your feedback is invaluable, the purpose of the following release schedule is to make the new chapters available to those who'd like to give me feedback -- I will love you for it! -- without blurting my half-baked writing across the internet.
  1. Draft
  2. Release Candidate (RC)
  3. Publication

Drafts to remain private

There is no good reason to make the drafts available to the public.

Release Candidates Available to the Public

Every week one new chapter shall be published to the blog, and the following week's chapter shall be added to a public folder on my Google Drive.  Click here to see this week's Release Candidate, i.e. the chapter to published on Friday-week.  (Not this Friday, but next Friday)

Published Chapters

Published chapters and a release schedule are available here.  Once a chapter has been officially published, it could still be amended, but I hope that by that point it'll be in good enough shape to require only minimal touch-ups.

Why should I be an editor?

Obviously, you will receive a king's ransom of virtual hugs from me if you critique a Release Candidate, which should be enough of a reason.
Also, I will happily mention you as an editor if you give me feedback or correct a typo.  This includes linking to your own blog or channel.
But I'd say it's mostly for the love.

entry.title: Chapter XI: Trousers' Report on Ogressia
entry.content:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/e-basak/5781414509/sizes/l
Trousers reported:

“This city, Ogressia, is in the middle of a vast quarry in the heart of a mountain range.  Those who first came here must have hollowed out solid rock.  The cave that we entered by, which they call the Old Entrance, is on the north side (or the dark side); at the southern end of the quarry floor is a tunnel that leads to an opening on the side of the mountain range.  Ogres file in and out of there all day, transporting supplies from the outside.

“Don’t tell me you went out there.”

Trousers stretched nonchalantly across her lap.  “I couldn’t very well investigate it from a distance, now could I?”

“Trousers, I told you to be careful!”

He nuzzled her stomach and in spite of herself Odessa stroked his chin.  “I was careful, but I was after all on my first official mission.”  Odessa moved to argue with him but he cut her off.  “ -- At any rate, they didn’t see me.  When I emerged into the open I saw where the ogres got all their food and supplies from.  On the mountain side and down into the valley, there are acres of lush grass, where the ogres keep teeming flocks of sheep, herds of cattle, tribes of goats, and droves of pigs, for which they built the grandest barns and sties I’ve ever seen.
“At the foot of the mountain range is a tremendous expanse of flat lands, which has been cultivated for crops of every kind.  They have all sorts of grains, vegetables, and fruit.  In addition to the cultivated land, I saw a couple of mines in the distance and a deep, dark forest from which they carrying loads of lumber.  From the looks of it, most ogres work outside from morning until night.”

“What about the ogres in Ogressia?”

Much the same.  All around the city the ogres are busy working -- they build, repair, mend, and carry all day long, except for midday and tea time.”

“What happens then?”

“It’s most curious.  When a gong in the middle of the city is struck at midday, all the ogres down tools and disappear into manholes around the city.  About half an hour later, the gong is struck again, and they re-emerge, with a large handful of food, which they gulp down, and then return to work.  When the gong is struck in the afternoon, they all rush to the amphitheatre, also known as the Ogre Dome.

“How wretched,” she whispered.


Trousers didn’t reply.  Odessa had obviously never been hunting; she didn’t understand the thrill of the chase, the power you feel coursing through your veins when you go in for the kill.  He unsheathed his claws reflexively; when she looked down at him, he looked up at her with with an expression of perfect innocence.

Odessa stroked him tenderly as she fell back against the wall and sighed.

“What about the ogresses?  What do they do?”

“I saw a few ogresses walking around the city; or sitting in circles eating and talking.  There were a few who seemed to be supervising the ogres outside, but they spent most of their time snoozing in the fields.”

“I wonder why they’re not allowed to work with the ogres,” Odessa mused.

“Maybe they don’t have to.”

Yamizert appeared at the front entrance.  Odessa and Trousers held their breath.  Yamizert walked unsteadily into her room, oblivious of their presence.  There was a dull thud as she flopped on to her bed; loud snores soon followed.

“Well done on an excellent report,” Odessa whispered.  “I can't say I'm pleased you took such risks, but at least you weren't spotted by anyone.”

“Well, there was one ogre who spotted me -- “

“Trousers! I told you to be careful!”

“Don’t fret Odessa, he handled me very gently --”

“Handled you? Do you mean he caught you?”

“It's funny you should say that –”

“Funny?  What do you mean?  Did he catch you?”

“Yes, he did catch me, but only because he shook the branches so powerfully – “

“ – Branches? Now what are you talking about?”

“Don't worry, Odessa, he's my friend now – “

“ – Friend? How can you befriend one of those monsters?”

“He's not a monster, Odessa, you just haven't got to know him yet.  His name is Tazagthrog and he's Turgolga's husband.“

Odessa caught the words that were about to fly from her mouth and considered Trousers' reply.

“Tazagthrog, Turgolga’s husband?  I saw him today during the Council meeting.  He seemed quite gentle, not at all the way Turgolga talks about him.”

“Yes, and the way he described her, you’d think he was her pet dog, although not nearly as stupid, of course.

“Trousers, dogs aren’t dimwits,”

“You only say that because they'll praise you to high heavens for the chance to chase a ball.”

“Let’s not get into that now.  Tell me about Tazagthrog, please.”

“I know this sounds strange, but he has a secret cave out in the forest in which he draws exquisite ink sketches on parchment.”

“Ink sketches on parchment?”

“Yes, he stumbled across a hidden cave one day and found a collection of sketches in there, which inspired him to manufacture his own parchments and even mix his own ink.”

“Where did he learn to sketch?”

“He’s a natural talent!  He didn’t even know the words for sketching, ink, or parchment, but he can draw like a savant.”

“What has he sketched?”

“He showed me a landscape sketch; a most flattering portrait of Turgolga on the day of their wedding, purely from memory; an exquisite view of the city from the top of those stairs we came down from; and a very strange scene that I can’t make head nor tail of.”

“What does it depict?”

“It’s a large burning wooden cross  in the middle of an open space.  It looks like someone is tied to the cross, but the way he drew it the flames almost completely obscure the victim.  I tried to ask him about it, but he clammed up and put the sketch away.”

“What do you think it means?”

“He clearly wanted me to see it, but more than that I cannot say.”

“Maybe he's not ready to tell you yet.”

“Perhaps.”

“Well, I’m proud of you, Trousers.  You have been very brave, although I must say you did worry me.”

“Don’t you worry about me, Odessa.  I’m a Pathfinder.”

“I know! And an excellent one at that.”

Odessa gave him a squeeze and a kiss and then turned on to her stomach to resume her sketching.  Trousers stepped curled up in the small of Odessa's back.  It wasn’t the most comfortable position for Odessa, but she couldn’t refuse Trousers a comfortable spot after all his hard work, now could she?  Her eyelids grew heavy and she put away her book.  She gently put the sleeping Trousers next to her on the floor, curled up around him, and soon fell asleep with his purrs in her ears.

The following morning, Odessa woke up to see Yamizert sitting next to them.  She had an ornate wooden box in one hand and a hunting knife in the other.

Yamizert kept her eyes locked on Odessa as she slowly lowered the knife into the wooden box.  “Get ready for Yugherkug’s Cleansing, we’re about to leave.”

entry.title: Chapter II: Meeting the Man
entry.content:
Chapter II: Meeting the Man


The crater was the size of a cricket oval; at its centre stood a lavish mansion.

Odessa scampered along the perimeter of the crater, looking for a way out.  She spotted an opening, but on closer inspection found no exit.  When she turned around, there was a man standing behind her.

Although the man was rather short, he was prepossessing in every other way.  He had hair like a news anchor and his face was almost impossibly smooth.  His slender frame was perfectly proportioned, and his small hands were decorated with red, manicured nails.  He wore a tailor-made navy blue suit and smart shoes with pointy toes.1

"I see you've made it all the way up my mountain," he said in a smooth, radiophonic voice, "most people are persuaded to join us a lot earlier.  Are you too good for us here?" he said in a somewhat joking manner.

He smiled like a game show host and stared directly into Odessa's eyes.  All the along the wall of the crater, a horde of staring faces with hollow eyes emerged, smiling with their mouths only.

Trousers peeked out from her backpack.  "Our summons instructed us to come see you."

"Really?" said the man. "Oh, my reputation precedes me!" The audience in the wall intoned words of approval.

- "Everyone wants to come here."
- "Coming here is a human right."
- "Everyone has a right to be treated equally."
- "Everyone has a right to be taken care of."

The man held his arms up and blew kisses to the faces all around, basking in their adoration, bowing and striking theatrical poses.

"What happened to Comrade?" Odessa asked, "What did he try to tell us? Why did they do that to him?"

The chorus died down; the man stopped his gesticulations and turned to face Odessa. His smile flickered and his hands clenched momentarily.

"Comrade was very sick, I am afraid," he said in a flat voice. "He was very confused and needed our help."

- "Yes, Comrade was selfish!"
- "We can't be selfish here."
- "We are all equal here."
- "Selfish people don't take care of each other."

"Are you the Man in the Mountain?" Odessa asked.

"Some call me that, but everyone here calls me Friend. We're all friends here, aren't we?"

- "Yes, we're all friends here."
- "We take care of each other."
- "No-one's better than anyone else."
- “We have coffee and cake here.”
- “Yes, coffee and cake.”

Odessa waited until the chorus died down. “Is this your mountain though? Everyone here looks up to you.”

The Man laughed at her compliment. “I don’t know about that,” he said with loud modesty, “I was merely the right man at the right time. I realised how unfair and selfish life was out there, and invited people to join me here, where everyone is equal and takes care of each other.”

- "Everyone wants to come here."
- "Coming here is a human right."
- "Everyone has a right to be treated equally."
- "Everyone has a right to be taken care of."
- “We have coffee and cake for everyone.”
- “Coffee and cake!”
- “Yes… coffee and cake for everyone!”

“Where do you get your coffee and cake from?”

The Man put his gameshow host smile back on. “From everyone, of course!”

Odessa felt her throat tighten. “I don’t understand.”

“It’s very simple, my dear woman,” the Man replied as hands sprouted from the floor around Odessa and started creeping towards her feet, “we all bring coffee and cake when we join, but some of us have to give up our coffee and cake for everyone else.”

The faces around the wall smiled and salivated.

- “Give us your coffee and cake!”
- “Don’t be selfish!”
- “We have a right to coffee and cake!”

Trousers whispered to Odessa, “What happens if someone wants to leave?  Comrade seemed pretty miserable about living here before the others tore him apart.”

Odessa pondered Trousers’ observation for a moment.

“But what if someone wants to leave?” she asked the Man.  “Surely some people would prefer to keep their coffee and cake.”

An expression of bewilderment wiped the Man’s smile off his face.  “What a strange idea, no-one wants to walk free. Life here is as good as it could be.”

“What do you mean, when you say that no-one wants to walk free?  Does that mean no-one here is free?” Odessa mused.  The creeping hands paused and perked up.

“Well, ah, no, I mean, that’s not right,” the Man stammered.  “What I meant to say is that no-one would want to leave.  Haha, what a ridiculous notion,” he laughed nervously.  “Yes, that’s it, no-one would want to leave!  Why would anyone want to leave a place that is perfect?” He turned to the wall for approval.  The faces stared at him blankly and one of the faces looked inquisitively at Odessa.  She skipped over the ring of hands around her and walked up to the inquiring face.

“What’s your name, Comrade?”

“It’s Comrade, like everyone else here.”

“Did you have a name before you came here?”

“Caleb.”

“But we don’t need to worry about something as self-centered as that.  We’re all friends here!” The Man interjected.

Odessa continued.  “Caleb, if you were free, you could leave or at least keep your own coffee and cake. But you’re stuck here, and you have to give up your coffee and cake if enough people want it, don’t you?”

“I suppose I’d have to, we mustn’t be selfish.”

“Come to think of, any of you here would have to give up yours if the others said so.”  She started pointing out faces around the wall, “You would have to give up your coffee and cake, and so would you, and so would you, and so would you over there!”

The faces that Odessa singled out looked around nervously as the attention of the crowd was drawn to them.  The mountain hushed and thousands of pairs of eyes turned to focus on Odessa.

"D-d-don't say that!" Caleb exclaimed, “we’re all free here, I’d give up my coffee and cake for the others, I’m not selfish.”

"But why is it selfish to keep your own coffee and cake? Are you really happy that all you do is allow someone else to walk all over you? Did you come here to be nothing more than a rock in a mountain?"  She turned back to the Man.  “And what about you?  You expect everyone else to give away theirs, but would you give up your coffee and cake for everyone else?”

Thousands of faces stared at Odessa in shocked silence. The Man tried grab her wrist but she shook him off with ease.  He stumbled back, regathered his composure and called out to the walls: "Come now, friends, enough of this selfish talk. We have everything we need, right? We're here for each other -- we love each other. Don't you remember how selfish life was before you came here?  Don't listen to this nasty woman, all she thinks about is herself, she just wants everyone to die in the middle of the street!"

Trousers whispered in Odessa's ear, "I see an opening down that way."
Odessa nodded and made a beeline towards the gap in the far end of the wall.

- "She's right, don't you see?"
- "She's selfish, don't listen to her."
- "But I've been thinking -- "
- "You've been thinking? Hey everyone, Comrade here has been thinking!"
- “It’s not Comrade, my name is Ethan.”
- “Yes, I’m tired of being called Comrade, it’s Zach to you.”
- “Yeah, I want to be called Hayden again.”
- “No, we’re all Comrade here!”
- “But I miss being called Brice.”
- "Selfish!"
- "You're selfish!
- "I'm not selfish, you’re selfish!”

Odessa quickened her pace. Arms shot out of the walls, snatching at faces, wrestling with each other. Rubbery grey, skeletal bodies poured out of the walls and collapsed on the floor, wheezing and wrestling and devouring each other. The mountain rumbled and swayed.

Odessa stopped at the opening; she couldn't make out what lay beyond. A small hand pulled at her hair -- "You! Look what you've done to my mountain!"

Trousers reared up from her backpack and slashed at the hand. It let go and Odessa wheeled around to see the Man.
But he was changed: his beautiful dark hair was dishevelled and patchy, revealing ugly spots and bumps on his head; his face was wrinkled and harsh; his eyes, wild and bloodshot; his teeth, yellow and sharp. His suit was shredded and barely covered his rubbery grey, flaccid body. Spittle formed in the corners of his snarling mouth and he nursed his wounded hand.

"I gave people what they asked for, everyone here was equal and we all took care of each other!" He exclaimed in a harsh, grating voice. "Now look at what you've done! No-one asked you to come here with your selfish ideas; people need to be protected from selfish ideas, otherwise everything will fall apart!"

He ran off, shouting, "Stop fighting, we mustn't fight! You all love me, don't you remember? We're all the same here!"

He tripped and fell on to a pile of fighting bodies. Startled by his arrival, they set upon him and he disappeared under a writhing mass of talons and teeth.

The mountain heaved.

“Are you ready, Trousers?”

“Ready when you are.”

She took a deep breath and jumped through the gap.

Odessa landed on a wooden sled that jutted out of the side of the mountain.  It broke off and she held on tight as it whizzed down the mountainside.  The mountain shuddered and cracked, and the floor of the crater dropped all the way to the ground.  Multitudes of bodies tumbled into the chasm, and the mountain collapsed in on itself.

Odessa and Trousers’ sled flew off the foot of the mountain and carried them through the air.  They sailed over a dark forest and landed in a pile of leaves in the middle of a clearing.  A path from the clearing lead to a cliff edge with a familiar white bridge that climbed into the sky. Under the Victorian street lamp was a sign that read "Bridge #15".

entry.title: Creative Commons, Free Culture, and a Modest Dream
entry.content:
The Odessia began, as is the case with much of my writing, with a dream.  When I was 19 years old, I woke up from a vivid dream and penned the following lines:
"Walking across a burning bridge, the fire consuming it behind me with every step I take, I am left with no option but to plod precariously along its creaking wooden gangplank.  Looking out across the dark depressive distance I see a line of fire-lit bridges to either side of me stretching out into the horizon..."
The story took me to the mountain, its inhabitants, and its creator.  My narrator escaped the mountain, but that is where the story ended, back in 2004.  I didn't know what the story meant or how to develop it.

Now, at the beginning of 2014, I have a dream, a goal, a sketch, maybe even a plan for the story.  No, it is not all laid out; no, I don't know how things will turn out for Odessa and Trousers, where they'll go, whom they'll meet, what they'll do, what they'll see.

However, there are a few matters of principle that will inform this project, for however long it may last.

Creative Commons and Free Culture

At the end of every chapter you will see this copyright blurb:
The Odessia by Alexander Garber is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.
Based on a work at http://theodessia.blogspot.com/.
Permissions beyond the scope of this license may be available at http://theodessia.blogspot.com/.
As long as you link back to me (Alexander Garber) and/or this blog (http://www.theodessia.blogspot.com), this means a few things:
  1. The Odessia is published free of charge. (Gratis)
  2. You may share copies of The Odessia with your friends.
  3. You may share copies of The Odessia on your blog or  website.
  4. You may use portions of The Odessia in a non-commercial creative work of your own.
  5. You may use portions of The Odessia in a commercial creative work of your own.
  6. You may print copies of The Odessia and sell them for profit, without paying me royalties.
All of this is fine by me, as long as you link back to me (Alexander Garber) and/or this blog. (http://www.theodessia.blogspot.com)

I have no intention of making money from book sales, but I do have a perhaps foolishly optimistic hope that people will like this story and share it around.  If enough people enjoy my writing, this might open doors in the future, but at the very least all I ask is that you link back to me and my blog if you share my writing.

A Scaffold for Others

It is my heart's desire that some of you who enjoy these stories will use these ideas and my imagery for your own creations.  If we all link to this blog and share these stories, then my work can serve as a platform for your sketches, your graphic design work (if you'd like to create a template for the blog, for example), your music, your audio production talent -- I will record readings --, your voice acting,  your video production, your animation, your acting on camera, your live performance, your translations, your editing, your own writing.

You are more than welcome to publish your material under a traditional copyright licence or a more restrictive Creative Commons licence.  My work shall remain free (both gratis and libre) and whatever you create with it will do nothing but flatter, inspire, encourage, and delight me.

Community and Friendship

Finally, the creative process can be a lonely road, especially writing, which lends itself to and sometimes necessitates long periods of solitude.  Moreover, I can't commit myself to anything more than a release-when-ready publication schedule, which means that it might be a long while between chapters.
However, if these stories serve as the basis for a host of other creative ventures, including other people's writing, we could build a whole group, club, maybe even community around these ideas.  I know it sounds fantastical, but I've seen similar things happen and it would be a dream come true to bring something like this to life.

Join, Share, Create

Thank you for reading this far; I really appreciate your interest.  I have no idea where this adventure may lead me and you -- if you'll join me on these travels -- but then again, neither do Odessa and Trousers.

If all of this isn't really your cup of tea, that's OK; if you could share the link around though, that would verily warm my heart.

Let me know what you think in the comments below, subscribe to my blog, and join our Facebook group if you haven't done so already.  Until next time, a safe journey to you all.

entry.title: Chapter XIII: Tazagthrog's Scars
entry.content:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/devosdelphin/3418388055/sizes/l 
Odessa grabbed her backpack and along with Trousers followed Tazagthrog through the city.  Ogres and ogresons were fast asleep in the hay; from some houses the sound of ogress chatter and laughter filtered through.  They arrived at the stairs to the Old Entrance; Tazagthrog ghosted up them and disappeared into the tunnel.  By the time Odessa and Trousers clambered to the top he was long gone.

By the light of her orb, Odessa followed the bright string she had left through the labyrinth to the back of the main cave.  The light from her orb faded as she stepped into the moonlight.  She put it in her pocket and tiptoed towards the Old Entrance, where Tazagthrog sat silently, staring out at the canyon.

“Odessa, what are you doing?” Trousers asked.  “Don’t let him see you!”

“Why not? He was gentle with you.”

“I know, but he came here to get away.  He didn't invite us here.”

“But he’s sad.”

“And what if he gets angry?”

“I don’t know.  But he needs someone to talk to.  Stay here and keep watch.”

Trousers wanted to pull her back, but he stayed behind in the shadows and watched her with frustration.  “Alright then, but be careful.”

Odessa approached Tazagthrog.  He spun around and towered over her.

“Who goes there?”

“It’s just me, Odessa.”

“Turgolga’s pet?”

“I'm not her pet,” Odessa said, “I'm a traveller.”

“Why did she let you follow me?”

“I don't think she knows I'm here.”

“Oh, I see.  Did anyone see you follow me?”

“I don’t think so.”

Tazagthrog picked up Odessa and held her up to his face.  His eyes were like stained glass windows and his fingers felt like anacondas.  His sulfurous breath made Odessa’s eyes water.

“Aren't you afraid of me?”

The orb pulsed warmly in Odessa's pocket; she looked down and saw that it glowed a gentle electric blue.  “I don’t think you’re as nasty as Turgolga says you are.”

“I’m not sure about that.”

He placed Odessa back on the ground and sat down.  He resumed staring into the canyon.  Odessa sat down next to him and followed his gaze to the gently moonlit rock.

“Are you happy that Yugherkug had his Cleansing today?”

“It had to be done.”

“But are you happy?”

“It doesn’t matter whether I’m happy or not.”

“It matters to me.”

Tazagthrog sighed and sank into silence.

“What was your Cleansing like?”

He pulled his feet in and wrapped his arms around his knees.  “I don’t remember much of it.  Turgolga was there; she delivered the knife to my mother.  The cutting hurts, but when the fire takes hold of you... nothing hurts much after that.” 

Odessa patted his arm.  “I’m sorry you had to go through that.  It doesn’t seem fair.”

“Life isn’t meant to be fair.”  His ears quivered in the moonlight.

“What was Turgolga like when you first met her?”

Tazagthrog’s mood lightened and he sat up straight.

“She was lovely -- I mean, she still is lovely, all ogresses are lovely -- but I remember when I first saw her.  She was tall and slender and very beautiful -- I mean, she’s even more beautiful now, ogresses are supposed to put on weight, but back then I thought she was very fine.  I remember once I stepped into her space in the square, and she could have punched my ear, but she just slapped and kicked me instead.  If her friends had seen that, they would have said she doesn't know how to hit an ogre, but I know she could have hurt me if if she wanted to.”

“Doesn’t it hurt when another ogre hits you?”

“Not much; you get used to it.”

“Is that because of your scales?”

“They help, especially against knives or fire.”

“Do the scales cover you entirely?”

“Almost, but I managed to keep one spot to myself.”

“May I see it?”

Tazagthrog remained silent.  Odessa pulled the orb from her pocket.  She held it up to Tazagthrog and its blue light grew brighter.  She moved it up along his arm across the front of his shoulder.  He pulled himself back from the edge and splayed his legs; she stepped over one leg and stood in front of him.  As she moved the light across his chest, a patch about the size of her hand in the middle of his chest glowed green. 

“You found it, Odessa.”

“Why do you keep it?  I thought ogres have to be tough.”

“I know I should burn it shut, but sometimes when I’m sad touching it makes me feel better.  If I lost this soft spot, I wouldn’t feel anything like that ever again.”

“Does Turgolga know about it?”

“No.”

“Why not?”

“I wanted to show it to her when I discovered it a few days after my Cleansing, but I didn’t want to disappoint her.  I wanted to be as tough as I could be for her; I wanted to deserve her.”

“She doesn’t seem very happy these days.”

“I know.  It’s my fault.  I do my best, but it never seems good enough.  She seemed different before my Cleansing; then again, maybe I’m the one that changed.”

His eyes shone like amber lamps from behind a craggy fortress.  His shoulders were stooped and a gentle groan escaped from him as he looked out into the canyon.

“Do you ever feel trapped behind all that armour?”

“Sometimes.  I miss being able to feel soft things against my skin.  I know an ogre isn't supposed to talk about such foolish things, but I wish I felt closer to Yugherkug and Yamizert; I wish... well... I wish I could...”

He lingered with his arms extended in front of him, searching for words that he had never learned and never had occasion to use.

“I don't think it's foolish at all.  We all need to be hugged sometimes.”

“Hugged?” Tazathrog asked as his hands dropped to his sides.

“Yes, it's when you put your arms around someone and he puts his arms around you.”  Odessa stepped up to Tazagthrog and stretched her arms across his oak-trunk abdomen.  Tazagthrog tensed and then relaxed.  His arms rose up and ever-so-gently ensconced her.

“You are so soft,” he remarked.

“You're not as hard as you look.”

“Do your people do this often?”  He whispered, as if afraid to break the spell.

“We do, although not often enough if you ask me.”

“How long do you, ah, hug each other for?”

“Sometimes, with really special people in our lives, we hug each other all night long.”

“Really?  And no-one punishes you for it?”

“No, we're safe.”

“I wonder what that would feel like.”

They held each for a little longer.  Odessa stepped back and looked up at this great creature, so immense and powerful, so vulnerable and forlorn.  She stepped forward and reached out to him.  As her hand pressed against the glowing green patch over his heart, he relaxed and slowly fell back on to the floor, like an old forest tree making its way back down to earth.

Odessa climbed on to his chest, knelt down, and placed her orb on his chest.  His scales were smooth and cool; his skin, like warm, rubbery velvet.  The patch glowed a fierce green as Odessa closed her eyes and leaned her weight in through her hands; suddenly, the orb melted into him and the patch changed to a brilliant electric blue.  The light spread across Tazagthrog’s chest, over his shoulders, down his arms, and into his fingers; it fanned out across his stomach and down his legs; it rushed up his neck and around his face.  The light grew brighter and brighter, whiter and whiter, until Tazagthrog and Odessa were engulfed by a cool white flame that filled the mouth of the cave.  In the middle of this noiseless explosion, Tazagthrog’s scales fell away and dissolved into ash.  The white light receded; in the darkness that took its place, Tazagthrog’s chest and limbs were crisscrossed with glowing blue scars.  Odessa sat up and placed her hands on her thighs.  She felt very tired all of a sudden.  She swayed, and toppled off Tazagthrog’s chest and on to the floor.  She struggled to stand up, stumbled a couple of paces, and then collapsed.

Trousers bolted out of the shadows.

“Odessa! Are you alright?”

He nuzzled her face and tried to wake her up, but Odessa lay still.

entry.title: Chapter XII: The Cleansing
entry.content:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/arash_rk/2380160367/sizes/o/
Turgolga emerged from her room wearing her finest jewellery, bangles, bracelets, and rings.  She placed the picnic basket in front of Odessa and Trousers.  “Let's go!”

Odessa and Trousers climbed into Turgolga’s picnic basket and this time they were carried by Tazagthrog, along with Yugherkug, Yamizert, and Turgolga to a grand square covered with a mosaic of stark tribal patterns.  At the centre of the square was a stage shaped like an altar, on which stood an imposing wooden cross.  At the foot of the cross was a bundle of firewood.

The square was filled with a crowd of ogres to the right and a crowd of ogresses to the left, with a path to the stage between them.  The ogres stood at attention, their eyes fixed on Yugherkug, their scaly faces blank; there was a buzz of excitement about the ogresses, although they paid little attention to Yugherkug.

Turgolga deposited the basket on nearby boulder.  Odessa with Trousers on her shoulder peeked out at the stage.
The Roundbelly family made its way to the front of the stage and turned to face the crowd.  Turgolga stepped raised her palms to the crowd; the ogresses hushed.

“Today is a proud day for the Roundbelly family.  I have tried to make the most of Yugherkug, but there is only so much one can expect from an ogreson.”  The ogresses in the crowd tutted and laughed in agreement; the ogres stood in silence, mostly staring at the ground.

“Ever since he was born, he has been a typical ogre.  If you tell him something once, you’ve told him it –“

“A thousand times!” Half of the crowd replied.

“And although I’ve been patient with him,” Turgolga continued, “there is no limit to the trouble he has caused.  But nobody said an ogress’s life was easy.”  Half the crowd shouted in agreement.

“Come, let’s not waste any more of your time on this filthy rock snake.  I should like to call upon my sisters to commence the Cleansing.”

Three ogresses stepped forward from the crowd and joined Turgolga in grabbing Yugherkug's limbs.  They tied him to the cross with ropes, his feet together, his arms out to his sides.  He looked down at Tazagthrog; Tazagthrog looked up at him, his body erect, his fists clenched.  For a moment, Odessa thought Tazagthrog was going to step on to the platform, but two ogres put their hands on his shoulders and he stepped back into the crowd; he put his arms around the shoulders of two large ogres in the front row.  They put their arms around his back and stood stiffly at attention with him.

Yamizert proffered the wooden box to her mother.  Turgolga opened it and held up the hunting knife to the crowd.  The ogresses cheered wildly; Yamizert left the stage and went to stand next to Odessa and Trousers on the boulder.  “What’s going on?” Odessa asked.  “Yugherkug’s Cleansing,” Yamizert replied in a soft monotone.  She leaned weakly against the boulder and stared at the ground.  “Aren’t you happy for your brother?” Odessa asked, but Yamizert didn’t reply.  Her pointed ears drooped and her arms were wrapped tightly around her midriff.

“With this knife, I trace our people’s struggle against the belly of the mountain.” Turgolga announced.  The ogresses in the crowd stamped their feet and clapped their hands to a slow, expectant beat.  Turgolga placed the knife against the front of Yugherkug’s right shoulder and cut a line to his left hip.  He gritted his teeth and clenched his body.  A row of bloody droplets was released like ropes from a bridge down his torso.  Then a long incision from his left shoulder to his right hip.  Then a series of crisscrossed lines across his chest and abdomen, his thighs and his arms.  All the while, Yugherkug gritted his teeth, but his moans were drowned out by the laughter and clapping from the crowd.  When Turgolga finished her knife-work, Yugherkug’s body from his shoulders to his feet was painted a glistening crimson that formed a pool on the stage and dripped down to the square.

Turgolga turned to face the crowd, the bloody knife in her hand, beaming with proud delight.  The ogresses ululated and clapped their hands.  Yugherkug looked pleadingly at his mother as she turned to face him.  She reached up to his left ear and deftly sliced off the top part.  Yugherkug screamed and writhed with such ferocity that Odessa could hear him over the banshee roar of the ululations and thought that the cross would break.  After a minute he dropped his head and gasped for breath.  Turgolga quickly moved across and sliced his other ear and then roughly rolled down the wounded portions to form neat, round ears.  Yugherkug screamed and writhed, as if an electric current were passing through him, until it too passed, and his head dropped again.

An ogress brought a burning torch to Turgolga and waved to the crowd as she exited the stage.  Turgolga brandished the torch and then applied it to the firewood at Yugherkug’s feet.  The kindling burst into flames; within seconds Yugherkug and the cross were engulfed in fire.

Odessa gasped in horror.  “Yamizert, what’s going on?  Why are they doing this?”

Yamizert kept on staring at the ground.  “It’s what we do.  Ogres have to be tough.”

“But he’s going to die!”

“No he won’t.  Not if he’s strong.”

The flames soon died down, leaving Yugherkug’s body completely charred.  The crowd fell silent again.  But then, a curious thing happened: reptilian scales began to push through.  From his feet to his head, except for his ears, the charred flesh fell off Yugherkug and within a few minutes, he was encased in a full body armour of scales.  The ropes and the cross disintegrated, and he collapsed on to the stage.  He tried to stand up, and when he looked at the crowd his sea-blues eyes had turned deep orange.  Tazagthrog rushed forward, slung him over his shoulder, and disappeared into the ogre side of the crowd.

Turgolga summoned Yamizert to the stage and officiously returned the knife to her, before patting her head affectionately.  The ogresses whooped and cheered; Turgolga waved to them like an opera singer and they dispersed.  Turgolga picked up Odessa and Trousers' basket and headed back home.

“Will Yugherkug be alright?”  Odessa asked nervously.

“Maybe now that he’s been Cleansed.”

Odessa looked at Yamizert who was walking alongside them, but Yamizert stared straight ahead.

When they got back to the Roundbelly home, Yugherkug was lying on the side of the road with Tazagthrog gently washing away the last of his charred flesh.  Yugherkug’s ears were bandaged.

That night, after Turgolga had drunk herself into a stupor and Yamizert had disappeared into the night, Odessa and Trousers heard voices outside.  They peeked out the front entrance and spied Tazagthrog and Yugherkug sitting next to each other with their legs crossed and their hands on their knees, facing the road.  Yugherkug scratched his sides.

“These scales are itchy, Father.”

Tazagthrog tensed at the word “father” and checked over his shoulder to see if anyone had heard them.  Odessa and Trousers pulled their heads in; when they peeked back out, they saw Tazagthrog’s right hand resting lightly on his son’s shoulder.

“I know Yugherkug, you’ll get used to them soon.”

They sat in silence, staring at the road.

“Why did I have to be Cleansed?  Was I dirty?”

“Some ogres say we're born dirty, and we have to be Cleansed to deserve being chosen by an ogress.”

“Do you say that?”

“I don't know.  But it makes us tough.”

“I know.  But why do we have to be tough?”

“If you aren’t tough, no ogress will choose you.”

“I heard that little creature that Mother brought home talking about their ogrefolk.  She said that their ogres don’t have to have a thick skin like ours; they’re allowed to be as soft as their ogresses.  Why can’t we be like that?”

“I don’t know, Yugherkug.  Maybe life is meant to be easier for those little creatures.  But we can’t change who we are.”

“It doesn’t seem fair.”

“Life isn’t fair, Yugherkug.  Now try to get some sleep: tomorrow you’ll start working with me in the Outside.  Working with the animals and the getting some sunlight will do you good.”

Yugherkug shifted to his bed of hay and was soon snoring peacefully.  Tazagthrog stood up quietly; his eyes glowed amber in the dark.  He turned around and walked down the road towards the great northern wall.

entry.title: Chapter VIII: A Conversation about Womanhood
entry.content:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/21183810@N00/3831421129/sizes/l/

Turgolga and Yamizert walked out the front entrance, leaving Odessa and Trousers alone in the living room.

“Trousers, I think I’ll have to stay here for a while until we can work out how to get away,” Odessa said quietly.  “And besides, I’d like to learn more about this Council.  In the meantime, why don’t you go exploring?  Just be careful of those horrible ogres, don't let them catch you.”

Trousers sat up very straight and puffed his chest.  “Don’t you worry about me, Odessa,” he replied, “I am a Pathfinder.”

“And besides,” he thought to himself as he zoomed up the rough stone wall and out through the window, “I need to show her that I’m more than a carry-on kitty.”

Turgolga returned with a decorated cube rock as tall as Odessa’s shoulders and placed it next to the floor table in the middle of the living room.  She gestured for Odessa to sit at the table with her.  Odessa hopped up on to it with a graceful wall-run.  Turgolga sat down with her legs crossed at the table.

“Now, tell me, little creature, what was your name again?”

“Odessa.”

“Odessa, yes, that’s right.  Tell me, Odessa, what does it mean to be a woman and what does it mean to be a girl?”

“It means lots of things, and it doesn’t always mean the same thing to everyone, but here's the way I see it.  When we're small, boys and girls can do pretty much the same things.  I always liked playing outside and climbing things, but even then I noticed that a lot of other girls preferred to play indoors.”

“Did you play with boys?”

“Yes! They were much more fun to play with than girls.”

“Wasn't it hard for you to keep them in check?  Ogresons are always so difficult to keep in line, if you give them an inch they'll terrorise you all day.”

“I didn't need to keep them in check; we just got along.  We didn't think much about the differences between us; we simply played.  Aren't young ogresses hard to raise as well?”

“Young ogresses can be tricky sometimes.  Take my Yamizert, for example.  She reminds me of myself when I was her age.  She asks a lot of questions, and doesn’t always see the obvious truth, but she’ll come around.  I look forward to the day when she joins me on the Council.  I worry sometimes that she’s a little soft on the ogresons, but she'll learn how to keep the ogre of her choice in his place.  Tell me, what happens when you get older?”

“As the boys grown into men and the girls into women, things change between us; it’s not as simple as it used to be.  When we're very young, boys and girls are about the same size; then girls get bigger than the boys; then before you know it, those same little boys are much bigger and stronger than we are.”
 
“Does that mean you have only a small window in which to teach the boys their place, while you are bigger and stronger?”

“I never thought of it that way, but I remember a girl called Susie who liked to hit boys.  For a while all the boys our age were afraid of her, but then one day Susie tried to hit a boy who had just had a growth spurt.  Instead of crying, he hit her back, and much harder than she had hit him.”

“Oh, how terrible! What happened to that nasty little creature?”

“She stopped hitting boys after that.”

“No, I meant the ogreson, I mean, boy.  Are boys allowed to hit girls?  Are men allowed to hit women?”

“Oh, well, boys aren’t supposed to hit girls, and a man who hits a woman would be in serious trouble, but in this case everyone knew how mean Susie was, so no-one said anything.  The other boys were quite relieved and the other girls didn’t like the way Susie had always carried on.”

“What a wicked society, if a boy can get away with hitting a girl!  Imagine allowing an ogre to hit an ogress!  It boggles my mind just thinking about it!”  Turgolga took a breath to steady herself.  “Well, Odessa, I’m glad you have a chance to see our civilised culture.  You have a lot to learn from us.”

Odessa nodded politely.  They sat in silence.

“Tell me, Odessa, why don’t you have a proper belly like mine?  Are all of your people so skinny?  Do you not have enough to eat?”

“Oh no, we vary quite a lot, especially when we grew into women.  Obviously, we get taller and stronger, but we also become softer, or rather certain parts of us get more squishy.”

“Ah, I see! Yes, that happens to us too.  I could see how the ogres started probing me with their stupid round eyes when I grew into a full ogress -- I had to hit quite a few of them for subjecting me to their ogre-gaze, let me tell you!” Turgolga laughed.  (Odessa laughed politely with her)  “I always longed for the day when I could show off my belly; I was so delighted when mine began to peek out from under my top.  Yamizert is starting to get a round belly, but, poor thing, she needs to eat a lot more if she is to achieve a respectable shape.”

“Where I come from, women generally prefer not to be so round, and most men like women who aren't very big.”

“That makes no sense to me.  Why would it matter what a man thinks of you?”

“It's not the be all and end all, but if there is a man that I like, and he doesn't find me attractive, then he won't want to be with me.”

“What do you mean, he won't want to be with you?”

“He won't go out with me, he won't be interested in me.”

“Do you mean to say that you ask him?

“Usually you don't have to ask; if he likes you, and you like him, then you’ll usually find a way to let each other know.  It can happen anywhere -- on the street, at a party, even in a hospital.”

“Does that mean you wait for him to come to you?”

“Well, I suppose I do.  If he’s really cute but shy, I might have to take the first step!”  Odessa smiled reminiscently into the distance.  “When I see someone that I connect with, and our eyes meet, and he starts walking towards me, I feel the most wonderful butterflies in my stomach.”  Odessa sighed.  “But if he walks away suddenly, those butterflies turn to lead.  And then you wonder whether it was all a dream…”
Odessa looked up at Turgolga.  “It's just the way it works for us, I guess.”

Turgolga shook her head.  “What a curious thought!  It would be the height of absurdity for an ogre to make advances on an ogress.  What would an ogre know about these sorts of things?  I chose Tazagthrog and that was that, although I sometimes wonder why I put up with him.”

“How did you meet Tazagthrog?  How did you know to choose him?”

“He came too close to me one day in the square, when I was sitting with my friends.  None of us was a Council Member back then, but we were already very wise in many matters.”

“Tazagthrog came too close?”

“Ogres must keep a respectable distance.”

“Why must they keep a respectable distance?”

“It would be scandalous for an ogre to violate an ogress’s space; we can’t allow those oafs to walk all over us and terrorise us with their large bodies!”

“What is a respectable distance?”

“Whatever an ogress wants.”

“What happened then?”

“I couldn’t allow this moron ogreson to humiliate me in front of my friends, so I jumped up to box his ear, but when I looked into those round blue eyes he had before his Cleansing, I was strangely reluctant to put him in his place.  I punched him just below the ear, but gave him a few good kicks to make up for it.  It’s shameful, I know; I could never tell a Council Member that I was so soft on him.  I don’t think anyone knows.”

“Didn’t that hurt him?”

“Ogresons don’t break as easily as your people.  We have to hit them very hard to get the message across, especially after they get their scales.  Anyway, as he dropped to the floor, I took care not to kick him too close to his ears.  After that day, I kept my eye on him.”

“To keep him in line?”

“Yes, of course, to keep him in line,” Turgolga said with a hint of a smile.  She looked into the distance for a moment and shook her head as if to clear away something inside her mind.

They sat in silence for a while.

“That was fascinating, little woman Odessa,” Turgolga said. “You women are the strangest, ugliest creatures I’ve ever seen, and I can’t say I understand how things work with you, but we ogresses have to work hard to keep the ogres in their place.  Maybe men are a little smarter than ogres.”  The strangeness of this idea made her snort mirthfully.  “Speaking of which, the Council for Creation and Improvement will assemble here shortly, so set yourself up in that corner there and try not to make any noise.  It’s almost time for breakfast, so I’m going to see where my good-for-nothing ogreman Tazagthrog is.”

Odessa lay down in the corner of the room and took a sturdy, leather-bound notebook from her backpack.  She unclipped a pencil from its cover and began to sketch absentmindedly.  She didn’t think herself much of an artist, but sketching and writing helped her to collect her thoughts, and she wanted to reflect on her recent encounters with the Man in the Mountain.  Was it really the Man’s fault that all those people got trapped in his mountain?  Had the Man always intended to make the mountain such a horrible place?  Maybe it wasn’t meant to be a mountain at all, just a place where people could live together and lean on each other in hard times.  From what the first Comrade told her (poor Comrade!), he had nothing but good intentions.  “Perhaps good intentions only count for so much,” she thought to herself.

entry.title: The Garden of Love by AJ Garber
entry.content:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/zedzap/9302868993/sizes/l/
Dedicated to my dear friends, Joël and Karen, on the first anniversary of their wedding. 
(Sunday, 2nd March 2014)

We went to the garden of love
And witnessed a living dream
A chapel was built in our midst
Of tenderness, honey and cream


A dance took place between us all
To the music of the breeze
In the sunlight’s speckled spotlight
We laughed and cried with ease


Our heartbeats clapped the rhythm
As the celebrant drew you near
The birds and wind held their breath
As your words rang true and clear


“I do, I do; we shall, we will”
The magic spell was cast
The birds resumed their chirping
Excited hands were clasped


In a circle in a house of love
Tears and kisses flowed
Words and songs brimmed with delight
Seeds of amity were sowed


Her right hand resting in his left
His arm had made its welcome claim
They were free to swing and twirl
No fear of falling in each other’s frame


Just the ever-present daydream
Of being swept right off their feet
With a tantalising movement
Executed to the beat
And indulgent recollection
Of the rare and cherished treat
Of being held
And being lead
And holding your attention


If only for a verse or two
I hold your gaze and you hold mine
And we’re amazed to see the twinkle of the star
That we wish upon in bed


A touch before we’d rest our heads
On our solitary pillows


And by the willow in our dream
We drift across a painted scene
While elderly couples recline
And reminisce and kiss


And as I drift back to the shore
I know there is a home for me
And as I come back from the road
I know there is a home for me
And as you reach the threshold
I feel your warmth reach out to me
And as you step inside our home
I hear your voice and it comforts me


And as we travel down this path
It matters not whereto
Mountains, valleys, desert ways
You have me and I have you.


But please ignore my wistful babble
No, please dismiss the things I said
My effervescent hopes
Must have gone straight to my head
Helped along for quite a while
By sips of port that make us smile
And with soft, illicit whispers
That rushed in like a tide
And left behind them blushing cheeks
And a crazy, foolish, silly thought
That caught in my mind
And wriggles around
And tugs at my shirt
And digs in my ribs
That maybe,
One day,
if you're free,
You might like to sit with me
And let me take your hand in mine
We'd put aside our charge of wine


And shrouded in each other's care
Underneath the starry skies
We could fill the summer air
With gentle whispers, hums, and sighs

entry.title: Chapter VII: The City of Ogres
entry.content:
http://farm1.staticflickr.com/233/517997642_bff0aa7382_o.jpg

The tunnel ended at the top of a flight of gigantic steps carved into the wall of a sprawling quarry.  From their vantage point, Odessa and Trousers saw a subterranean metropolis of winding roads and cavernous, pot-shaped buildings.  The city was alive with ogres carrying loads on their shoulders, hewing rock, repairing roofs, cooking on great coal bonfires, carrying huge buckets of water into the houses, and climbing in and out of a network of tunnels.

“Welcome to our city,” Turgolga said proudly.  The sound of brass gongs rang out.  “Today’s Games are about to begin.”  The ogres in the streets downed tools and were joined by others from houses and tunnels: the horde made its way to an amphitheatre directly below Odessa and Trousers, at the bottom of the stairs, some waving green flags, some waving blue.

“That looks exciting!” Odessa exclaimed.

“I suppose so,” Turgolga sighed.  “Only an ogre can enjoy the same thing every day.”

“Don’t you like to watch the Games?”

“Some of the sillier ogresses find them amusing, but a decent ogress soon tires of them.  It’s nothing more than a bunch of ogres bashing each other’s heads in.  If you’ve seen it once you’ve seen it a thousand times.”

“Do you think we could watch the Games today?”

“Well, I guess you might find them novel, but I’ll have to carry you in.”

She walked down the tall stairs; Odessa and Trousers clambered down after her.

Turgolga motioned for them to climb into a large picnic basket that she had left by the steps.  “I can’t let you walk unprotected.”  They made their way to the upper level of the amphitheatre’s stands, which were mostly empty, save for a few young ogresses who were talking amongst themselves.
The lower level was packed with wildly excited ogres, who were jabbering and jostling for space.  The crowd was awash with blue and green.

Odessa and Trousers climbed out of the basket and sat next to Turgolga on the stone bench.
The other ogresses were about seven feet tall and had dark yellow, rubbery skin.  The ogres were at least eight feet tall, barrel chested with slightly rounded bellies and muscular, tree-trunk arms and legs, and were covered from head to toe in dark brown reptilian scales.  All the ogres were bald, had round orange or yellow eyes, and small, neatly shaped round ears.  They wore animal skin loincloths and were barefoot.  The ogresses wore animal skin skirts and tops or dresses, and leather sandals; they adorned themselves with all manner of trinkets, patterns, and markings.  As most of the adult ogresses were quite fat, their clothes did little more than accentuate their folds of flesh and the rotundity of their stomachs, which Odessa soon discovered they displayed with pride.  They had wiry black or grey hair past their long, pointed ears and slanted yellow eyes.

Two teams of large ogres filed into the centre of the amphitheatre, one group wearing blue armbands, the other wearing green.  They lined up against each other.  “Those are the Demes,” Turgolga pointed out, “half the ogres follow the Blues, half follow the Greens.”

“How do they decide which to follow?”

“It generally runs in families.  My son Yugerkug supports the Greens, like his, ahem, father, Tazagthrog.”

“What about you?”

“I suppose I would pick the Greens if I had to, but Council Member ogresses have better things to do than pay attention to what ogres get up to in the Dome.”

An announcer wearing a blue and green robe, waved theatrically to the crowd, which responded with raucous cheers and chants.  The announcer give a signal, a loud gong sounded, and the two groups proceeded to brawl ferociously until only one fighter with a green armband was left standing.  As the ogres in the centre did battle, the crowd erupted like enraged baboons, and fights broke out all around the stadium.  By the end of the official fight there were dazed ogres strewn about the stands.  For a while the noise died down as those left standing sat down for a rest, and after a while the rest of the ogres picked themselves up and groggily dusted themselves off.

“My goodness,” Odessa said, “do ogres always carry on like this?  Isn’t it dangerous for you and the other ogresses?”

“Ogres enjoy fighting and killing; it’s pretty much the only thing that makes them happy.”

“Did you say they enjoy killing?”

“Yes, that’s why the next Games are with animals.”

Odessa watched in horror as gargantuan pigs and bulls were lead into a pen in the amphitheatre.  The master of ceremonies gesticulated theatrically and pointed out random ogres from the crowd, who whooped with delight.  The volunteers lined up at a gate and when one of the animals was released from the holding pen, the nominated volunteer took off after it.  The animal, terrified by the roar of the crowd, ran around the sand frantically, trying to find a way out and kicking or biting whenever its hunter drew near.  One by one, each animal was chased down and beaten to death.  Sometimes when an animal was knocked down, the triumphant ogre put his fist through its skull, or ripped its head off, or held it up to the baying crowd before ripping out its jugular.  Each time an animal’s life was extinguished the spectators went wild with ecstasy, and occasionally an ogre from the crowd rushed into the centre, grabbed the animal’s corpse and flung it around like a ragdoll.  Others rushed to remove him, which led to another brawl, to the crowd’s delight.  Eventually, all the animals were killed, and their remains were carried off in large sacks by the proud volunteers.  The ogre horde streamed out of the amphitheatre, chanting and clapping and whooping like gorillas.  Silence and the smell of blood filled the air.

By this time, Odessa had climbed back into the basket, pale and weak with disgust.  Ogres bashing each other senseless was one thing, but torturing animals for sport?  She felt ill.  During the running of the bulls, Trousers stayed outside the basket and stood at full attention, his eyes wide open and his ears pricked up.  Odessa reached for him from the basket but he remained glued to the action until she pulled him in.  When she let go of him, he skipped out of the basket and continued watching attentively.

As they made their way through the streets, Odessa and Trousers peeked out of the basket.  The ogres had returned to work by then.  As Turgolga walked passed them, they instinctively stopped working, stooped their shoulders to bring themselves to her level, and dropped their gaze.  Turgolga cursed the ogres that didn’t move quickly enough out of her way, and when an ogre carrying a large rock brushed against her as he stepped aside, she wheeled around and slapped him powerfully across the face.  He rocked back, regained his balance, and quickly moved away.

“I suppose Turgolga has to be stern with them, otherwise they’d rip her apart,” Odessa mused.  “She must be brave to walk the streets with these nasty brutes about.”

As they passed a large square in the centre of town, Odessa and Trousers noticed groups of young ogres (known as ogresons) and young ogresses playing separately.  Both groups were almost as tall as adults; the ogresons’ skin was smooth and dark yellow, and they were much more slender than the adult males; unlike the adults, they all had large pointed ears and blue or green eyes.  The young ogresses were tall and lithe, with long braided or dreadlocked hair and almond-shaped yellow eyes.  The ogresons played boisterously -- wrestling, picking each other up, jumping acrobatically over each other.  The young ogresses mainly sat in circles and talked all at the same time.  An ogreson absentmindedly brushed against an ogress who was chatting with her friends; she leapt up and punched his ear.  He dropped to the ground clutching his head, and the ogresses and his own friends set upon him, screaming, kicking, and punching until he crawled away from their attacks.  He sat sulking for a while and massaged his wounded ear.  “It seems their ears are the only part of them that hurts,” Odessa remarked.  “I wonder why none of the adult ogres have pointed ears,” Trousers mused.

They arrived at a large round house that was carved entirely from solid rock.  Turgolga strode through the front door and deposited the basket on the floor.  Odessa and Trousers climbed out into a vast living room with a low table in the centre.  Straight in front was a doorway that led the bonfire in the backyard, to the left and to the right were bedrooms, immediately outside the front entrance Odessa had noticed two sections neatly covered with hay. 

“What’s the hay out the front for?”

“Don’t mind the mess over there,” Turgolga said with embarrassment, “that’s where the ogres sleep.

“Which ogres?”

“Tazagthrog and Yugerkug of course!  I know I should make them sleep in a ditch somewhere, but I’m too soft for my own good sometimes.”

“Don’t they sleep in the house?”

Turgolga snorted.  “What a strange idea!  Where do you imagine I’m supposed to put them?”

“Where I come from, you and Tazagthrog would sleep together, in the same bed.”

“Look here,” Turgolga said, with her hands on her hips, “I don’t know what sort of things you little people do, but I’m a respectable ogress.  According to the elder ogresses it borders on scandalous that I allowed Tazagthrog into my chamber on two occasions, especially after the first time produced an ogress.  Once Tazagthrog finished the lowly work on our home, his place has been either outside the front door or in the kitchen.  As I was saying, I’ve told them both a thousand times to keep their hay tidy, but they never listen.” 

She tutted in annoyance and then remembered her duties as hostess.

“At any rate, welcome to my home! I’m going to design a meal for Tazagthrog to make when he gets back from work, but first let me introduce you to my children.  Yamizert, Yugerkug, come here!  I’ve got a surprise for you!”

Yamizert, a young ogress, emerged from the bedroom on the left and Yugerkug, an ogreson, walked in through the front door.  Yamizert stood at her mother’s height, had her mother’s wiry hair, pointed ears, and slanted yellow eyes.  She was so slim (as far as ogresses were concerned) that her stomach barely protruded from under her top.  She looked suspiciously at Odessa.

“Ew! What is this ridiculous insect?  I wanted a cow to play with or at least something big enough to eat -- this, uh, this thing isn’t even worth a snack!”

“She’s not a ‘thing’ and she’s not for eating, Yamizert,” Turgolga explained, “she’s a -- what are you again?”

“I’m a woman,” Odessa said, “although some people think I’m still a girl.”

“What’s the difference?” Yamizert asked.

“It’s something to do with climbing trees,” Turgolga replied.  “Now, please, Yamizert, you can’t eat her and you can’t play with her either: I think she breaks easily.”

“Whatever she is, I think she’s silly.  I don’t know why you waste my time with this rubbish.”

“Now now, Yamizert,” Turgolga said patiently, “she’s a very interesting creature.  Please be careful with her, that’s all I ask.”

Yugerkug was Yamizert’s younger brother.  He was already the height of an adult ogre, although his limbs were not as powerfully built yet.  He had large pointed ears and his body and face were smooth except for a couple of small patches of reptilian scales on his arms and legs.  His round sea-blue eyes were bright with curiosity.  “Mother, she’s like a tiny hobgoblin! Wha’ we gonna call her?”  He asked as he took a step towards Odessa to a better look.

Turgolga quickly stepped up to Yugerkug and slapped him viciously across the face.  Yugerkug crashed on to the floor.  Odessa and Trousers ran to the far end of the room.  “Don’t you dare speak to me like that, you filthy toad!” She screamed.  “How dare you speak to an ogress in that tone of voice!”

Yugerkug squirmed on the floor and held his hands up to protect his face.  Turgolga grabbed his wrists in one hand punched him on the side with the other.  “Keep your mouth shut or I’ll give you a real hiding.  Speak to an ogress when you’re spoken to, understand?”

Yugerkug was not sure whether to answer or not, so he nodded his head energetically.  Turgolga kicked him in the ribs.  “And don’t you dare touch my pet woman, or you’ll be in serious trouble.  Now get out!”  Yugerkug scurried out of the house.

Turgolga stomped towards Odessa and Trousers and towered over them, her shoulders heaving, her nostrils flared.  She took a deep breath and smiled calmly.  “I’m sorry that he got so close to you.  I try so hard with him, but I can never be sure what he’ll get up to next.”

Odessa tried to keep her voice steady.  “I understand, I’ll try to be careful.”

entry.title: Chapter III: The Piano in the Park
entry.content:
Chapter III: The Piano in the Park



Bridge #15 took Odessa and her feline companion, Praetorius Pathfinder XII (known to his friends as Trousers) to an island in the clouds, and deposited them on a platform on the branch of a tall oak tree.  Trousers rode in Odessa’s bag as she climbed down a rope ladder.  When she reached the ground, she found herself in an English garden.  In the distance was a village on top of a hill.  The sunlight through the leaves created a speckled pattern on the manicured grass.  Odessa put away her jacket and top and felt a delicious shiver as the sun stroked her face and arms.

They followed a nearby gravel path through a small forest and into a clearing, at the centre of which stood a black piano.  There were three other paths that lead to this clearing and a large sign that read, “Play me, please.”  Two small children, a brother and a sister ran up to it and sat down together on the piano stool.  They banged away at the keys with noisy delight and their parents, who arrived soon after, said, “Well done, Sebastian, what will the little maestro think of next?” and “Yes, Esmerelda, that sounds beautiful!”

Odessa stood next to the piano and waited patiently for her turn.  She loved seeing little children at play, but she was also itching to get her hands on it; although she was not an accomplished pianist, anyone who plays knows how enticing those black-and-white keys can be.  Even a modest player like her could envelope herself in layers of music with nothing more than simple patterns and the sustain pedal.  Odessa was wont to overuse the sustain pedal, but out here in the forest, she intended to indulge this guilty pleasure.

“May I play the piano on my own?”  Esmerelda asked.

“Alright then,” her mother sighed.  “Sebastian, come here, you’ll have a turn after her.”

Sebastian folded his arms and pouted.  His mother put her hand on his arm and gently guided him off the piano stool.  His sister revelled in her unfettered access, and her little hands eagerly explored the keyboard in search of new keys to jump on.

Sebastian whined, “It’s not fair!” and tried to climb back up.  Esmerelda pushed him off the stool and recommenced playing.  Sebastian whined more loudly and sent his little fist into his sister’s back.  Within an instant both children were in tears.  Their mother looked at Odessa, pursed her lips, rolled her eyes, and sighed out of her nose.  “This is my life,” she said, “at least I’m never short of drama.”  She and her husband took the crying children off to the side.

Trousers jumped up on top of the piano and reclined above the middle of the keys.  Odessa sat down at the piano and played an upbeat, simple waltz; she bobbed her head a little and pulsed to the beat through her shoulders.  Esmerelda stopped crying and her parents allowed her to approach the piano.  Odessa noticed the girl mimicking her movements .  Her brother continued to protest: “No, it’s not fair, I wanna play!”

“Sebastian, if you don’t calm down and let this woman play in peace we’ll go home and you shan’t get to play the piano at all,” his father said in hushed tones.  Sebastian’s cries geared down to a steady sob.  “No, I wanna play it on my own!”

The mother mouthed an apology to Odessa; Odessa smiled and shrugged.  With only a couple of slips, which the casual listener never notices anyway, Odessa finished the song with a delighted trill.  Esmerelda giggled and clapped her hands.  Odessa turned to her and bowed her head.  Sebastian’s father continued to reason with him in vain: “Come on now, let’s listen to this woman play, she’s very good, isn’t she?”

Sebastian’s mother, embarrassed by her son’s behaviour, asked Odessa to play another song.

Odessa placed her hands on the keyboard and stopped.

“What’s the matter?” Trousers asked.

“I wish that little boy would stop making such a noise.  I haven’t had a chance to play for such a long time, and now that I’ve got this beautiful piano, I can’t play it in peace.”

“Maybe the boy is thinking along the same lines,” Trousers replied.

Odessa was a little annoyed that Trousers did not commiserate with her, and turned around to look at Sebastian.  He looked dejectedly at her with tears in his eyes.  She turned to Emerelda, whose excited grin had been replaced with an embarrassed frown when she had turned to see her brother.

“I wonder if there’s something I can do,” Odessa said to herself.  “Would you like to play with me, Esmerelda?”

Esmerelda nodded cautiously while looking at her mother.

“Oh you don’t need to do that, I’m sure she’ll keep quiet,” the mother said to Odessa.

“This next song needs a partner, maybe even two,” she replied with a conspiratorial smile.  The mother took a moment to register Odessa’s meaning and her face lit up.  “Oh, I see, yes, that’s a good idea.”  Odessa directed Esmerelda to sit on the right side of the seat.  She gave Esmerelda a simple treble pattern to play over and over, and then layered a progression of arpeggios and chords over it with the middle keys.  They played for a few bars and Esmerelda squealed, “Look, Mummy, I’m playing a tune!”

“Well done, Esmerelda, that’s wonderful!”

Sebastian stopped crying and walked up to the piano.  “Daddy, may I play too?”

Odessa nodded to the father and brought her ditty with Esmerelda to a close.  “That was grand, Esmerelda!” Odessa said, “Could you do that again?”  She nodded excitedly.  “Alright, now just wait a moment…”

She directed Sebastian to sit on her left and gave him a simple walking bass line in the same key as his sister’s treble pattern.  After a few attempts he got used to it.  “That’s it, Sebastian, keep on doing that; Esmerelda, repeat what you played for me...” After a bit of correction and encouragement, Sebastian and Esmerelda fell into the same rhythm.  Odessa proceeded to layer chords, arpeggios, trills, and other combinations between Sebastian’s bass line and Esmerelda’s treble pattern.  The two children concentrated quietly on their respective tasks and their parents held hands in breathless silence.  In a clearing in a forest in a garden in the sky, Odessa and her small companions made simple, happy music.  When the song had run its course, she placed her right hand on Esmerelda’s hands; the treble fell away; she placed her left hand on Sebastian’s hands; the bassline fell away; she played a final flourish and finished on a major chord.  The clearing hushed.  Odessa turned around and the parents clapped and shouted, “Bravo! Bravo! That was wonderful!”

Odessa directed her fellow players to stand up with her; they faced their audience hand in hand and took a bow.  She then placed Sebastian’s hand in Esmerelda’s and led them to their parents.  “Oh, that was marvellous,” the mother gushed.  “Thank you ever so much for putting up with them.”

“All I did was listen to what they were trying to say.  They wanted to make music and I showed them how they could do it together.”

“Tell me,” the father interjected, “are you a professional musician?  You could make a good money doing that sort of thing.”

“I can perform in front of a crowd, but I never had the discipline to master the piano.  I always liked to try lots of different things.”

“Well then,” he replied, “you must be very talented.  I could have been pretty good at the piano myself, but I focused on other things too, and now that we have a family, it’s hard to find the time.  Isn’t that right, darling?”  She nodded with an expression of weary sagacity on her face.  “Yes, it all changes when you have children.”

The family walked away hand in hand and Odessa sat back down at the piano.  Trousers hopped up on her lap.

“I tried to explain to them that I wasn’t putting up with the children, but rather listening to them.  Do you think they understood me, Trousers?”

“I suspect they listened to you as carefully as they do to their children.”

“In that case, I think they can expect a lot more drama in their lives.”

“I’m afraid so.”

Odessa gave Trousers a quick scratch behind the ears and concentrated on the piano.  She ran through her modest repertoire, stumbling here and there, adding a little flourish of her own on occasion.  Although she enjoyed performing acrobatics or theatre in front of a crowd, she found it harder to allow the music to take hold of her when she had an audience, at least a human one, that is.  When she finished playing, the birds chirped their applause and the trees around her whispered in approval.  By this time Trousers was snoozing contentedly on her lap, and it took her a while before she could bring herself to shift him.  Rousing a sleeping cat from one’s lap always takes time.

They followed a path that took her to a patch of grass next to a stream.  She lay down and Trousers settled in the small of her back.  She drifted off, listening to the song of the breeze.
