entry.title: Introduction: The Crossings
entry.content:
"And our sports shall be seen
On the echoing green" -- William Blake

Sometimes, when a cat settles on your chest, gazing at you with his dreamy, half-closed eyes, he thinks of an eternally sun-kissed green.  An occasional breeze caresses your face and dances through your hair.  The air is alive with chirps, buzzes, hums, and the fluttering of butterflies and ladybugs.  The grass is lush and soft; the trees, which are perfect for climbing, burgeon with ripe fruit of every kind. And the air is perfumed by daffodils, tulips, buttercups, and clusters of thornless roses.

Every cat will visit this green at some point; it's in his nature.  However, if he disappears, never to return, it is because he has been summoned to guide a traveller over The Crossings at the end of the green.  This is a great honour.

The green gives way to a dusty, gravel track at the edge of an inky abyss that extends into the horizon.

And it is here that our story begins, when Odessa traversed the green and arrived at The Crossings.

Odessa came from a family of travellers. Although she was sad to leave her mother and father, brothers and sisters, she felt it had to be that way.  She also missed their travelling menagerie -- the musings of her cats, the chatter of her birds, the exclamations of her dogs, and even the anxious complaints of her guinea pigs.  From time to time, she inquired after her family from passing birds, and all the reports were that they were getting on well without her, but that they missed her all the same.

She wore soft, flat-soled boots, a pair of men’s cargo pants with a simple leather belt, a fitted T-shirt, and a lightweight long-sleeved top.  She carried all her belongings in a magical backpack, barely bigger than a pouch, that was infinitely bigger on the inside; no matter what you put in it, it was always weighed next to nothing.
She had long tight black curls that cascaded over her shoulders and face and bobbled energetically.  When her dark oak brown eyes, set underneath a pair of bold black eyebrows, focused on you, you could almost feel the information being syphoned.  And when someone she especially loved held her close, she liked to purr softly and brush his cheek with hers.

But there was no-one that she especially loved anymore.

The sunlight drained away as Odessa stepped on to the gravel path; a cruel wind cut through her clothes, its tendrils at her throat, face, and ears.  During her approach, the abyss had crept up into the sky; now the green, barely an arm's length away, seemed a mirage.  She put on a long jacket, a small silk scarf, and a pair of gloves from her backpack.

All along the precipice is a row of wrought iron archways.  Through each archway is a broad gangplank, hovering in mid-air, that leads to a glowing white hanging bridge, suspended from nothing.  Some of the bridges disappear into the sky, some into the abyss, some straight ahead.  At the beginning of every bridge is a Victorian street lamp that shines with a faintly blue white light, to which is attached a white sign with a number in black.

A well proportioned ginger tomcat stepped into the light of a torch that was fixed to a nearby archway.  His fur was divided into neat patchwork squares, some ginger, some auburn, some brown, and his four white paws looked like dainty gloves.  His hind quarters were very fluffy, which gave them the appearance of billowing trousers from behind.  He sat down somewhat officiously and looked up at her with bright hazel eyes.

"Oh what a lovely kitty!" She exclaimed.  "I wonder where you came from."

"My name is Praetorius Pathfinder XII," he replied in Queen's English, "but my daily name is Trousers.  I am your guide."

Odessa's eyes widened with delighted curiosity.

"What kind of a cat are you?"

Praetorius's chest puffed up with pride.  "I come from an old adventuring family.  Every first-born tomcat in my family for eleven generations -- ahem, that is, now twelve generations," he corrected himself, and seemed to swell even further, "every tomcat in my family has received a summons to guide a traveller over The Crossings."

Odessa didn't understand the significance of Praetorius's lineage, but she could see that he held great store by this fact.

"Why do they call you Trousers?"

No sooner had she asked, than he had stood up and displayed his voluminous hindquarters, arching his back and reaching out with his front paws in order to emphasise their length and shape.

"Oh, I see.  You do look very elegant."

"Much obliged."

"Well then, I think I'll call you Trousers if you don't mind."

"I don't mind at all."

Odessa regarded his sleek, patchwork-pattern coat, his fine bushy tail, his shapely ears, and his agile, dignified comportment.

"I must say, you are a handsome cat."

Trousers licked the top of his front left paw and then used it to pat down a tuft of fur on his head.  He was particular about his appearance, and although he was never surprised to receive such compliments -- he being a well proportioned ginger tomcat, after all -- he was pleased.

"Trousers, where are we?"

"We are at The Crossings.  It is time for you to choose a bridge."

"Are you sure?" Odessa asked, "can't I just turn around and go back?"

"I have been summoned," he replied with an air of finality.

They stood in silence for a while before Odessa spoke:

"But there are so many bridges -- "

" -- one-hundred-and-eighty-one to be precise -- "

"Yes, but which shall I choose?"

"According to my summons, your first destination is the Man in the Mountain.  After that, we shall have to work it out together."

"What do you mean, my first destination?  Can't I just come back afterwards?"

"You can only cross each bridge once, and every bridge takes you to a different place."

Odessa frowned.

"I'm not sure that I want to cross any of these bridges.  Maybe I'll go back and play on the green instead.  Maybe I should just go home."

"Why did you leave home?"

She sighed.  There were many things she wanted to say, but thinking about it made her feel tired.

"It was time to go," she said simply.

"And why did you leave the green?"

Odessa was not sure about that.  When she first got to the green, she thought she would never leave, but after a while she started wishing she had someone to purr and cuddle with.  The more she thought about that, the more she had felt drawn to the ugly darkness on the horizon.

"I was looking for someone," she began to say, "and now that I've met you we can return to the green together! Yes, you're what I need -- let's go back to the green!"

Trousers sat back down in silence.  His bushy tail tapped the ground behind him a couple of times and then lay flat.  He waited for her to continue.

But Odessa hesitated.  She didn't like to admit that she was afraid, but the prospect of not getting back home had knocked her off kilter.  She turned to the green, so distant now it seemed, and then sat down on the gravel with her legs crossed.  She shivered in the cold and hugged herself, feeling worn out and a little lonely.  Trousers came and curled up in her lap.  She stroked his head and his purr sounded like a cross between a bumblebee and a diesel engine.

"Trousers, I'm afraid," she whispered.

He didn't like to admit that he wasn't as confident as he seemed, but he reminded himself that a courageous cat is an honest cat.

"So am I, Odessa," He muttered with his chin on her forearm.

"But what shall I do?"

"If you return to the green now, you will never find out what is on the other side; if you make your first Crossing, you will only get back to the green at the end of your journey.  But we can brave our fear together if we both accept it."

Odessa gave him a gentle squeeze.  He felt like a plush hot water bottle, and his purrs sent warm waves into her belly.  He had always enjoyed being stroked and held, and found it difficult at times to remain sufficiently aloof.  At any rate, there were no other cats around to see him and he did feel less anxious about his formidable assignment.   He rolled on to his back and allowed her to stroke his stomach as his head lay on her hip.

"In that case," Odessa said finally, "I should like to make a Crossing.  Which bridge leads to the Man in the Mountain?"

"Bridge #90."

And so Odessa followed Praetorius Pathfinder XII through the archway, walked the hovering gangplank, and stepped on to Bridge #90.  With every passing step, the wooden slat behind her burst into flames like a giant match, dissolved into ash and drifted down into the abyss.

"There's no turning back now," Odessa said.

"I'm afraid not," he replied.

entry.title: Chapter X: The Council
entry.content:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/geralds_1311/5957218085/sizes/l
Odessa’s scribbling was interrupted by a hubbub outside the front entrance.  Turgolga was followed into the front room by a procession of high ranking ogresses who together constituted the Council for Creation and Improvement (known generally as the Council), which oversaw all matters of chief importance in the city of Ogressia.  The chieftanship of the Council rotated between the hostesses of each meeting; from now until the next monthly meeting, Turgolga would sit at the head of the table.
All the ogresses adorned their corpulent frames with elaborate necklaces, beads, and bracelets; they stood at attention around the great stone table facing Turgolga, who began:

“Esteemed members of the Council for Creation and Improvement, I call today’s meeting to order.  Let us begin with a call of present members:
“Thugherga?” – “Bellowblast!”
“Ragudda?” – “Blackheart!”
“Gaghregga?” – “Thunderstone!”
“Kuzrobbina?” – “Oxenrider!”
“Serarka?” – “Cannonfist!”
“Marghbartha?” – “Shadowback!”

“And I, Turgolga Roundbelly, chieftan of the Council for this moonspan, am of course present.  Before we begin, I have something to show the Council.  Odessa!”

Odessa approached the table.  The ogresses stared in astonishment.

–- “My goodness! What is the bizarre little creature?”
–- “It looks like a baby hobgoblin.”
–- “Uglier, I should say.”
–- “Is it dirty?”
–- “It doesn’t look dirty.”
–- “Turgolga wouldn't bring a dirty creature into her home.”
–- “Of course not.”
–- “Still, it looks nasty.”
–- “And skinny too.”
–- “Yes, eerily skinny.”
–- “Where did it come from?”

Turgolga motioned for the Council to let her speak.

“This creature is called a ‘woman’ and I found her near the Old Entrance.”

“The Old Entrance?”
“How did she get there?”
“It must have been magic!”
“Don’t touch her, she might give you scales!”

“She is harmless to touch, dear Council members.  She has trained as a performer: isn’t that right, Odessa?”

“Yes, Turgolga.”

–- “Ooh, a performer!”
–- “We love a good performance.”
–- “What did you think of last night’s drum dance?”
–- “The young ogresses are getting better, but ogresses these days are far too skinny.”
–- “That’s what they said about us before we came of age.”
–- “I know, but they can’t move if they don’t have anything to move with.”
–- “Too true”
–- “It's almost as if they're worried about looking good for the ogresons.”
–- “Ha! Don't be ridiculous!”
–- “You always say the most outrageous things, Serarka.”
–- “Not as outrageous as some of the outfits those emaciated ogresses were wearing last night, Kuzrobbina.”
–- “I thought they were rather weak, if you ask me.”

“Council members, please! Let us sit down and let our little visitor perform for us.”

The ogresses sat down heavily around the table.  Turgolga motioned for Odessa to climb up and put on a show.  Odessa hopped up nervously on to the table and looked around.  Even though Odessa stood comfortably above her spectators, she felt herself to be easily within their grasp.

She faced Turgolga and raised her arms out to her sides.  She clapped a slow steady beat with her hands and indicated that the spectators should follow suit.  The ogresses clapped along with her: “clap (two-three-four), clap (two-three-four), clap (two-three-four)...”
Odessa bent backwards into a bridge, kicked her legs up, and settled into a handstand.  The ogresses sighed appreciatively and continued their rhythmic clapping.  She walked rhythmically along the table on her hands, straddled her legs, and lowered her legs down to a seated straddle.  She closed her legs, rolled backwards into a candle, and popped up into a handstand, and came back on to her feet.  She stepped to the beat of the claps, twirling her hands and sweeping her upper body around.
She did a neat cartwheel off her left foot, then a neat cartwheel back off her right; a one-handed cartwheel, then another the other way; an aerial cartwheel (hands up neatly at the end), and then an aerial cartwheel the other way; a butterfly kick one way and then the other, and finally a butterfly twist, out of which she went into a spot turn, and corkscrewed down until she ended with her legs crossed facing Turgolga.

“Marvellous! Marvellous!” Turgolga exclaimed.  The rest of the ogresses clapped enthusiastically.

–- “What a clever little creature!”
–- “I’m too dignified to move like that these days, but I could do that in my day.”
–- “Oh yes, I too, before I chose my ogreman.”
–- “Yes, you can’t do anything with an ogreman around.”
–- “They never get anything right.”
–- “Nothing at all.”

Odessa took a bow and hopped off the table.

“Thank you, Odessa,” Turgolga announced, “now let us get down to business…”

Tazagthrog appeared at the doorway, his head bowed, his hands placed over each other at the height of his bellybutton.  Turgolga motioned impatiently for him to come in and he quietly slipped past them into the kitchen.  “Always so noisy and slow, my ogreman Tazagthrog” Turgolga said and the others hummed in agreement.  “I don’t know why I granted him my presence, but I suppose he could be worse.  He’s almost not too stupid sometimes.”

“He’s very lucky to be with you, Turgolga.”
“I know, Thugherga, but he makes me feel so unappreciated sometimes.”
“That’s how they are; try as you might, you can’t change them; you can only do your best to keep them in line.”

A few minutes later, Tazagthrog appeared with a titanic platter of cooked meat and vegetables, and a plate so small that it barely covered the palm of his hand.  He placed the platter on the table, and surreptitiously deposited a tiny plate (by ogre standards) in front of Odessa before whisking out.  The ogresses pounced on the platter and devoured its contents, shovelling great handfuls of meat and vegetables into their mouths with much grunting and burping and smacking of lips.  They washed their food with cupfuls of ogre wine and beer, and within a short while the entire platter had been picked clean.  Odessa could barely move after eating her portion of meat and vegetables  The ogresses sat back, not entirely satiated, and Turgola shouted to the entrance, “Tazagthrog, we need to talk!”

Tazagthrog appeared at the doorway; Turgolga got up clumsily and walked into the kitchen.  Tazagthrog followed her in there and sounds of hitting and angry whispers emerged through the doorway: “Embarrass me in front of my guests… tiny portion… useless… pathetic… I don’t know why… well cook some more… you’ll just have to try harder next time…”

Turgolga re-emerged from the kitchen and sat down at the table.  “I am terribly sorry for his incompetence.  He never gets it right.  I created the meal for him, but, yet again, he couldn’t make it properly.  Sometimes I think I should just make it myself.”

– “Don’t say that, Turgolga!”
– “You’re so patient with him.”
– “I don’t have such restraint with my Teggrut!”
– “Come now, it was a respectable appetiser.”

Mollified by the encouragement of her friends and the sight of their swollen bellies, Turgolga’s mood lightened and she commenced the meeting of the Council.

For the rest of the day, the Council for Creation and Improvement discussed such matters as which ogreman was the most incompetent, whether beer or wine went best with ham, and whether ogres should be made to sleep outside the front door or in the square.  They also discussed Yugherkug’s impending Cleansing:

– “Tomorrow’s the big day for your ogreson, isn’t it?”
– “It’s about time, ogresons are so ridiculous without a proper set of scales -- all those muscles showing through, it’s so indecent.”
– “And ogresons are so rowdy before their Cleansing”
– “Yes, it’s a shame they can’t be initiated at birth”
– “You’ve survived with him until now, what’s one more night?”

Eventually, the Council for Creation and Improvement drew its meeting to a noisy close and the ogresses filed out of the Roundbelly home.  Tazagthrog speedily cleared the table and gathered the leftover food.  He left another minuscule portion (by his reckoning) near Odessa and glanced briefly at her.  When she smiled at him, he immediately dropped his gaze and disappeared into the kitchen.  A few moments later, he hurried past her and out the door with a handful of food.  Odessa heard the rustling of hay as he lay down for the night.

Turgolga belched a few times, stood up unsteadily, and staggered to her bedroom.  She filled the doorframe with a perfectly sized obelisk and a few moments later, Odessa heard her crash into bed and start snoring.

Odessa walked to the front entrance and peered around the corner.  Tazagthrog lay still on his bed of hay, but as his eyes looked half-open, she wasn’t sure whether he was asleep.  A small ginger shape flashed past her and she turned around to see Trousers reclining on her backpack.  His bushy tail tapped her bag excitedly as he groomed his paws and stomach with energetic precision.

“Trousers!” she whispered as she lay down next to him, “where were you?  Are you alright?”

Trousers ceased his grooming and curled up in her arm, his face nestled under her chin.  “I have completed my scouting mission.”

Odessa squeezed him with delight.  “Go on, what did you find out?”

Trousers cleared his throat and commenced his report.

entry.title: Chapter IX: The Catacombs
entry.content:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/bichologo_errante/4860134538
Trousers worked his way up the rough stone wall of Turgolga’s house and climbed on to the thatched roof.  As the ogres’ dwellings were bunched together, he decided to explore the area by hopping across rooftops.  The adult ogres went mechanically about their day, carrying loads, breaking stones, building, repairing, cooking.  They moved with heavy deliberation and said very little.  Many of the ogres were accompanied by adolescent apprentices – a blacksmith banged away while his assistant pumped the bellows, two labourers, young and old, shuffled down the road with obelisks on their backs, a butcher slaughtered gigantic livestock while his assistant held them down.

Through the windows of some of the houses, Trousers saw groups of ogresses sitting in circles, talking animatedly, waving their arms and slapping their enormous thighs.  Here and there, little ogresons ran between houses and bounced around the open spaces; and young ogresses walked around in small groups, or sat in circles talking loudly at each other and slapping their trim thighs.

At the edge of the quarry a wide, dimly lit tunnel.  Trousers slipped behind some rocks near the entrance and peeked inside.  There was an inviting light in the distance.  He slipped inside and kept close to the walls.  Ogres transporting goods in clomped past those on their way out; no-one took any notice of Trousers as he sneaked through the shadows.  He emerged into the fresh air and made his way through the grass to a tall tree, scampered up its trunk, and surveyed the land.

The tunnel into the ogres’ city was halfway up a mountain, at the foot of which lay a sprawling, green, cultivated plateau.  Far into the horizon stretched neatly divided plots of land, some blanketed with crops, some filled with orchards, some covered with lush grass and populated by livestock.  Ogres trundled to and fro, working the land, carrying baskets of produce, and herding animals.  Some lay in the hot sun and snoozed, others sat on their haunches and quietly ate fistfuls of fresh food.  Trousers noticed that few of them talked to each other, and none of them sang.  An ogre came by and sat back against the trunk of Trousers' tree.  As there was nothing nearby for Trousers to jump on to, he paced carefully along the lower branches and got ready to scamper down the trunk behind the ogre's back.

“Take your time, I’ve come here for a nap,” the ogre said sleepily, looking ahead into the distance.

Trousers froze.  The ogre turned around and looked up at him.

“Hello, little thing.” the ogre said.

“Hello,” Trousers replied cautiously.

My name is Tazagthrog and I belong to Turgolga.  What's your name and whom do you belong to?”

“My name is Trousers and I don't belong to anyone.”

“I see, you haven't been selected by anyone yet.  Nice to meet you, Trousers.”  Tazagthrog settled back against the tree and stared into the distance.  “Feel free to come down, but don’t let the others see you -- they might want to play with you.”

“I’ll stay here for a while, if you don’t mind.”

“I don’t mind at all.”

Trousers climbed up a little higher.

“What sort of creature are you, Trousers?”

“I’m a cat.”

“And what does a cat do?”

“We do lots of things.  Some of us hunt mice and rats -- “

“What are mice and rats?”

“They’re little furry creatures --”

“ -- even smaller than you?”

“Yes, even smaller than we are.”

“How strange.  What else do you do?”

“Some of us own people -- “

“Is that creature you came with one of them?”

“Yes, she’s a person.  A young woman to be precise.”

“And what do you do with your people?”

“We don’t have to do very much with them, they’re usually very well behaved.  They bring us food and drink, and build houses for us, and set aside places for us to sleep, and are always happy to see us.  We put up with them and allow them to rub our bellies and that spot just above our tails which always feels splendid.”

“How do you acquire people?”

“Sometimes they are arranged for us before we are born; sometimes we have to scout out a suitable family and scratch at their door for a while.”

“Does that woman you came with belong to you?”

“In a way she does.  I received a summons to be her guide, so I have to watch out for her.”

Tazagthrog closed his eyes and Trousers watched him suspiciously from the top of the tree.

“Would you like to see something I made?”  Tazagthrog asked suddenly.

“Where?  Here?”

“No, over there,” Tazagthrog replied, pointing to a hill rising up from a forest in the distance.  “I keep ‘em in there.”

“I’m really not sure,” Trousers began, but Tazagthrog reached up to the branches and shook them.  The entire tree rocked as if in an earthquake, and Trousers dropped into Tazagthrog’s basket-like hand.

“Well, if you insist…” Trousers said.

Tazagthrog marched across the grass into the trees.  They arrived at a large boulder at the foot of the hill.  He shifted the boulder aside to reveal a tall, narrow tunnel, and took Trousers into the spacious cave at its end.  The cave contained a catacomb filled with clay jars.

Tazagthrog carefully extracted a few jars from the wall, each sealed with a neatly trimmed piece of leather that was secured with a string.  He held Trousers out in front of him and stared imposingly.  “You won’t run away.  Promise?”

“I promise.”  Tazagthrog put Trousers in one of the sections of the wall, up high.  Intrigued, Trousers watched as Tazagthrog undid the strings, removed the covers, and extracted a collection of animal-skin parchments.

“What are those, Tazagthrog?”

“These are my, ah… I don’t actually know what to call them, but I made ‘em,”  Tazagthrog replied bashfully.  He squatted down, unrolled the parchments and laid them on the ground with polished stones on their corners to keep them flat.  On each parchment was an exquisite sketch in black ink -- the landscape, a view of the city from up high, the face of a pretty young ogress with long braided hair and a cheeky grin, and a row of burning wooden crosses in the middle of an open space.  Each sketch had a crude, almost childlike quality to it, but there was no doubting the skill or care of the artist.

“Did you draw these?”

“Ah… well… yes.”

“These are fine sketches!”

“Sketches?”

“Yes, that’s what they are, aren’t they?”

“I don’t know.  I’ve never talked to anyone about them before.  I didn’t know they had a name.”

“So who taught you how to do this?”

When I discovered this place it already had lots of these.  It was smaller when I found it, but I ran out of space, so I widened it.  There were more of these, ah, sketches (his mouth rolled around the word carefully), and they're much better than my ones.  Also, I didn't know how to make the special black paint.”

“You mean the ink?”

“Yes, ink,” he said carefully, “sketch, ink, sketch, ink...” he murmured to himself.  “I worked in the coal mines so I can make a lot of... ink – “ Tazagthrog pointed to a large mound of black coal, “and when Megork Granitegut disappeared, I took over from him in tanning the leather, so I could make more of these special skins.”

“Do you mean parchments?”

“So that's what they're called! You are very clever.  How do you know all these names?”

“Where I come from, many people do what you do.”

“Really? Are they allowed to?  Don't they get in trouble?”

“Not usually.”

“But they must be punished.”

“It might happen, if someone important gets upset about a sketch – it has happened before.”

“I thought so!  Do they have to face the Council?”

“What do you mean?”

“If you do something wrong, you have to face the Council.  No-one wants to face the Council.”  Tazagthrog shuddered briefly as he stared into the distance.

They were silent for a while.

“Why did your friend disappear?”

“What's a friend?”

Trousers opened his mouth to reply, but stopped himself and thought carefully.

“Are there any other ogres who know about this place?”

“I don't think so.”

“Does that mean you haven't told anyone else about it?”

“I'm not supposed to be here.”

“Is there no other ogre you can show this place to?”

“I'm not supposed to be here.”

“What would happen if another ogre found you here?”

“Oh,” Tazagthrog's shoulders slumped, “I would have to face the Council.  You won't tell anyone, will you?”

“Of course not!” Trousers still didn't fancy his chances of escaping the cave.

Tazagthrog looked up at Trousers.  “What's a friend?”

Trousers considered his reply.  “A friend is someone you can tell a secret to, and he won't tell the Council.”

Tazagthrog stared intently at the floor.  “Does that mean you're my friend?”  He asked quietly.  Trousers paused and Tazagthrog looked up from the floor at him with wide open eyes and bated breath.  In that moment Trousers felt himself to be staring down at Tazagthrog from an imperious distance.

“Yes, Tazagthrog, you could say we are,” Trousers replied reassuringly.

As Tazagthrog allowed the response to sink in, a warm smile spread across his rough face.  He returned to his sketches.

“D'you like 'em?”

“They're superb! Tell me, why did the other ogre disappear?  Where did he go to?”

“No-one knows what happens to 'em.  I sometimes wish I could disappear too.”

“Why?”

I sometimes wonder if there isn’t something better, and besides, I don’t really count for much, no-one would miss me.  But then again, what could be better than having food to eat, and hay to sleep on, and an ogress to belong to?”

“Tell me more about these sketches, please,” he said.

Tazagthrog pointed to the landscape.  “This is my first, ah, sketch.  One of the goats strayed from the flock and I went up the hill to find him.  When I looked at the land from the top of the hill, it made me, ah…” Tazagthrog looked around the floor as if he lost something.  “It made me feel as if I’d eaten a big feast, only without food.”

“Do you mean to say it made you feel happy?”

“What does that mean?”

“I suppose you could say it’s when you are neither hungry nor thirsty, neither angry nor in pain; when all the things that bother you fade away and everything else feels good.”

“Yes! When I stood there looking at the land from the top of the hill, I didn't want to hurt or kill anyone, or even break anything.”

“Are you saying it felt even better than hunting?”

Tazagthrog sat down with his legs crossed and pondered this question.  “Better than hunting?  I don't know.  I always thought that hunting was the best.  It was different.  Hunting in the Dome is what we all dream of; but no-one ever talks about this quiet feeling.”

“And so you sketched the scene that made you feel happy, right?”

“Yes, happy,” He said slowly.  “And whenever I look at it, I feel that feeling again.”

“That means it's the best kind of sketch, Tazagthrog.”

Tazagthrog smiled with embarrassment, rolled up the parchment, and put it away.

“What about the sketch of the ogress?”

“That’s Turgolga,” Tazagthrog said with a wistful smile.

“Is that when she was younger?”

“Yes, the day I become hers.”

“She seemed lovely.”

“Yes, she’s perfect.  I don’t know why she chose me.”

“Why don’t you show her this?  I’m sure she’d love to see it.”

“I’m not supposed to be here.”  Tazagthrog rolled up the parchment and put it away too.  He made to roll up the rest.

“Your sketch of the city is incredible!”

Tazagthrog stopped and looked up at Trousers with a proud smile.  He sat back down next to his sketch.  “Thank you.  It took me a long time.  It's the view from the top of the stairs to the Old Entrance.  I like going there.  It’s quiet there.”

“I know what you mean.  Before I left my home I had a place that I liked to go to.  Sometimes I would sit and think; sometimes I’d just sit.”

“Yes, I sit here and think too,” Tazagthrog replied half to himself.  He looked up.  “Do friends sit and think together?”

“Yes, we certainly do.  Sometimes that’s the best thing friends can do.”

“You’re a good friend then, little Trousers.”

“You're a good friend too, Tazagthrog.”

entry.title: Chapter IV: Trousers and Waistcoat
entry.content:
Trousers woke up from his nap and shambled off Odessa’s back.  He yawned and stretched. Odessa stirred in her sleep and turned on to her side.  Trousers helped himself to a quick nuzzle of her nape.  “Let’s go exploring,” he said to himself.

He made his way back to the piano and took the third path from the clearing.  It meandered through the garden, up the hills, and through a maze.  At the centre of the maze sat a life-sized statue of a cat on top of a brick wall.  As Trousers approached it, the grey stone skin melted away and the statue came to life.

“Welcome, young Trousers, we have much to talk about.”

Trousers sat before the venerable ginger tabby.  He had long white whiskers and the fur from his midriff to his shoulders was pitch black.

“Who are you?”

“I am Praetorius Pathfinder, but my daily name is Waistcoat.  Congratulations on receiving your summons.”

“Pathfinder Waistcoat?  As in Praetorius Pathfinder the First, who travelled with Gudrid the Viking across the frozen ocean to the New World?

“Yes, I am he.  After Gudrid settled in the New World, I received a second summons to accompany Lusita the Light Bringer.”

“Is it true that you guided Lusita through the Dark Valley of the giant black wolves?”

“We helped each other get through, it is probably fairer to say.”

"What did you find on the other side?"

"We found a gate in the rock that lead to a path through the Black Forest, past a clearing, to the bridge that leads to this garden in the clouds."

“Are the stories about the giant black wolves true?  How did you make it through?”

“Lusita’s willingness to step out of the shadows had more to do with our survival than we in the feline world give her credit for.  But that’s a story for another time."

"Will you ever return to your old family?"

"Not unless I receive a new summons, but I have already answered two.  And besides, many generations have passed since then.  I like to keep an eye on their descendants from here though.  I’m pleased to see that they haven’t gone in for this fashion of owning fluffy little dogs -- I can’t take those walking bathmats seriously."

"Don't you miss them?"

"Of course I do, but my place is here now.”

Trousers sighed.

“I wish I could be as brave as you.”

“Oh, Trousers,” he laughed, “you make it sound terribly grand.  To be honest I was often freezing and terrified; most of the time I had no idea whither to go or what to do!”

Trousers stared at his paws.  “Then you know how I feel.”

“Tell me more.”

Trousers scratched the ground in front of him and looked to the side.  “I’m not sure I am up to this task, Grandfather Waistcoat.”

“But, my dear cat, you have been summoned; and you’re a Pathfinder, no less.”

“Maybe there was a mistake, maybe I was supposed to remain a house cat.”

“A summons is never issued by mistake.”

“I know, that’s what Grandfather Buttons always said.”

“Ah yes, Praetorius the Tenth.  He had a very dapper set of black spots on his belly, but he had his moments.  Do you know that when he lead Peregrin the Pilgrim over The Crossings he nearly fell off the bridge?”

Trousers stared at his ancestor in amazement.  Waistcoat sauntered along the brick wall, pretending to nervously cross a bridge, looking back and veering off to the side until he allowed himself to drop off the edge.  Trousers burst out laughing and they both giggled like kittens.

“I thought I was the only one that could happen to!” Trousers exclaimed between fits of laughter.

“So did I,” Waistcoat replied mirthfully as he rolled on the ground and pretended to fall through the air.

Trousers laughed anew at Waistcoat’s antics and they both jumped up on and dropped off the fence, allowing themselves to fall over when they hit the ground.  After a final round of laughter, they both returned to their dignified sitting.  Waistcoat stretched and Trousers followed his lead.

“Don’t be ashamed to nuzzle Odessa and purr into her chest, or be stroked and held by her.  You two will be together for a long time.”

“I always thought that a cat is supposed to be more dignified than that.”

“Humbug!  Once you receive your summons, helping your traveller is supreme.  None of us had the foggiest idea what we were supposed to do, but if there is one thing I learned from my travels, and from watching those who went before you, it is that Odessa will need your love, counsel, and protection more than anything else.  There will be times, young Trousers, when you feel like nothing more than a carry-on kitty, but always remember that you were summoned for a reason.”

Praetorius Pathfinder the First returned to his original position, closed his eyes, and turned back into stone.  Trousers rubbed his head against the statue and he went on his way.

Thank you! I'm very pleased you enjoy the descriptions. I have a lot of ideas and there are general themes I wish to explore, but I expect the story to take shape over the next few months. I'm getting a better sense of who Odessa is and what her function in the story will be, but I need to give it time. You'll get to see a lot more over the coming chapters.

entry.title: New Chapters for January and February 2014
entry.content:
See the Published Chapters for details of the release schedule to follow.

First of all, many thanks to the people who have given me feedback and shared Odessa's first adventure, The Man in the Mountain. (Chapter II and Chapter III)

Especial thanks to my friends Timotej Kovačič and Ann M. Tedeschi-Davidson; Timotej has been invaluable behind the scenes and Ann's sketches of Odessa are a real delight.  Remember, these stories are released under a Creative Commons licence, so if you feel a surge of creativity when reading them, you already have permission to use this material!

Chapters IV to X: In the Ogres' Lair

Odessa's next adventure will take her to a dangerous, violent place, populated by enormous men and women.  However, by the end of her time there she will come to see that first impressions can be misleading.

Release Schedule

For the next seven weeks a new chapter shall be released every Friday afternoon. (Australian time)  This will take us from Friday the 17th of January 2014 until the 28th of February 2014.  By that time I hope to have a new batch of chapters lined up, but as I have to balance this project with work and studies, I can't make any promises yet.

Fear and Feedback

I am very new to writing with a view to publishing my work, and truth be told it is very frightening.  I am often beset by the fear that it's all clumsy rubbish; that no-one in his right mind would want to read it -- it's too long, too short, too predictable; it's contrived, unoriginal, uninteresting.
So I write and rewrite until there is nothing else I can do to make it better -- that's not to say I am satisfied with it, but I can only go so far under my own steam.

And this is where you can really help me.

I'd like to find an editor (anyone interested?) to review the stories before I publish them, but, either in addition to an editor or in place thereof, I'd like you, my readers to be my crowdsourced editors too.  Let me explain:

When I studied Shakespeare at university one of the most striking things that I learned about him was his method of writing; that is, he would change the script in response to feedback from the audience.  It is said that Shakespeare would watch the audience during the performance of his plays and take note of when they cheered and applauded and when they got bored or booed the players.  English audiences were very vocal back then.  If people liked certain dialogue or characters, Shakespeare worked more of that material into the play; if the audience didn't enjoy other parts, out they went.  This meant that the final version of the script could be radically different from when it was first performed; whether it had more artistic merit is debatable, but one thing was for sure: the audiences loved it, and I suspect that this is one reason for Shakespeare's enduring success.  He didn't have an elevated view of himself as an artiste; he had an incredible talent for telling stories, and had plenty of stories to tell -- or rather plagiarise by today's nauseating standards of copyright -- and did his utmost to write plays that communicated his ideas and kept people entertained.

What I mean by all this, to return to our little project here, is that I would love your feedback -- your encouragement of course, but especially your criticism.  What do you think of the characters?  What do you think of the descriptions?  Does the plot flow?  Does it stretch the suspension of disbelief?  What would you like to see more of?  What would you like to see less of?  How does reading this make you feel?

Wiki-style Editing

Following this invitation to shower me with your feedback, understand that these chapters are not set in stone.  If, months or years from now, you discover this novel and think of something I could do better, even in Chapter I, I will still be open to revising it.  That's the beauty of an online novel -- there is no final draft that I have to submit to a publisher, no deadline, no word limit.  Naturally, with the passage of time there will be less and less need or justification to alter the earlier chapters, but that doesn't mean it'll ever be out of the question.  I hope that as Odessa's adventure unfolds, we'll all get a better sense of who she is and how she'll interact with the characters she meets.

For now, I hope you enjoy her adventure in the ogres' lair.

Mission DevOps is now Mission WebDev.  Nothing much else in the blog will change, but it represents the next stage in the evolution of my career as a software developer.  Since I updated my online profile to reflect this, I have attracted more interest, which is always a good sign.  I am working my way through a couple of courses online to lay a strong foundation for front-end development, so in this pomodoro cycle I have covered, inter alia, the following topics:

  • Basics of CSS

  • Basics of JavaScript:

NodeJS (Mostly theoretical)

  • Node core
  • modules, exports, require
  • Events and the Event Emitter

Study Goals

My goal for the next pomodoro cycle is to complete the following courses online:

Learn and Understand NodeJS by Anthony Alicea

It's not an easy course because Alicea goes deep into the Node core and takes the time to explain concepts in tremendous detail.  I'm taking lots of notes getting a lot of gestalt moments.

JavaScript: Understanding the Weird Parts by Anthony Alicea

I'm so impressed by Alicea's treatment of NodeJS so far, that I trust his JavaScript course will give me the deep understanding I'm looking for.

The Web Developer Bootcamp by Colt Steele

I'm finding it to be a great educational framework.  I've put it on hold until I complete the other two courses, and will probably park it in order to supplement my knowledge in other areas, but it's the best overall guide to becoming a web dev that I've found so far.

Coding Challenge

In addition to the course, I've set myself the challenge of working my way through last year's Advent of Code in JavaScript.  If I can complete all these challenges, I'll be satisfied with my proficiency in JavaScript and be confident in mastering a web development framework.

React or Vue?

I'm still undecided, but it's probably not something I'll have to address before I hit 1,000 (!!!) hours in my mission to become a fully fledged (and employed) web developer.

See you in a hundred pomodoros.

entry.title: Chapter VI: The Cave in the Canyon
entry.content:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/kateure1309/6455246227/sizes/l/

Bridge #135 took Odessa and Praetorius Pathfinder XII (known to his friends as Trousers) down from the sky into the depths of a grand canyon.  They arrived at the opening of a cave high up in the wall of the sheer cliff.

As they stepped off, the final slat exploded in a rush and the rest of the bridge disintegrated in the morning sunlight.

Odessa’s shadow stretched into the cave, but beyond the entrance it fell into darkness.

Odessa pulled out of her bag a pearl-coloured orb that fit comfortably in the palm of her hand.  It had been a birthday present from a strange old man who joined her family on their travels for a while.  When they set up their stalls and street performances, he walked around town chatting with people and somehow always convinced them to buy something or see a show.  He never rushed, yet he always got everything done.  He wore flowing clothes and had a long white beard; he was the only adult Odessa had met that could speak with her animals. 

Any adult can talk with animals, but somewhere along the way most adults forget how to listen, first to animals, then to children, then to each other, and finally to themselves.  Animals worked this out a long time ago, which is why dogs make lots of gestures and noises, and cats bring us dead birds; they find it hard to see how we adults can take care of ourselves when we have forgotten how to listen to our own bodies.

On Odessa’s seventeenth birthday, the old man sat down with her and placed the orb in her hand.  “As long as you look with an open heart and think kind thoughts, the light of this orb will show you the way,” he said.  It now floated from the palm of her hand and hovered like a little lantern over her head; they left the sun-lit mouth of the cave and examined their surroundings in the light of the orb’s gentle white glow.

Trousers sniffed the air suspiciously.  “I don’t like the smell of this place,” he said.

The cave narrowed to a tall, broad tunnel.  There were animal bones strewn on the floor and and brown smears on the walls.  They reached a fork in the tunnel; they stood there, wondering which way to go, when they heard lumbering footsteps and the sound of bodies dragging on the ground coming from the tunnel to the right.
They stepped into the tunnel to the left and looked back into the main tunnel.  The outline of a pair of giants came into view.  One dragged a collection of gargantuan sheep, goats, and cows behind him on a rope; the other carried a bundle of firewood under his arm.

“Let’s have a one of these as a snack at the Old Entrance.”  The first giant said in a deep, slow, almost childlike voice.
“Good idea, I’ bin bashin’ rock all through the night and I’m starvin’,” replied his friend, in a slightly less deep, but equally uninflected tone.
“You ain’t starvin’, you fa’ oaf, you’re a greedy troll”
“Who you callin’ a troll, you goblin!”

And the two giants continued walking, exchanging clumsy insults and pushing each other into the wall, which sent vibrations through the rock.

“Trousers, what were those men?  I’ve never seen anyone so big in my life!”

“We are in the ogres’ lair.  My grandfather, Praetorius Pathfinder X (known to his friends as Buttons for the dots on his belly) passed through here once.  He said the ogres are very stupid, but if they get a hold of you, they think it good sport to use you as a plaything -- and they play very rough indeed.  He also said to beware of -- watch out!”

And before Odessa could turn around, a pair of huge hands reached out of the shadows, grabbed her by the waist and lifted her high into the air.  Odessa’s vision was filled by a pair of huge yellow eyes and big yellow teeth.  Trousers scampered back into the entrance tunnel and watched helplessly as the ogress held Odessa aloft like a doll.

“You’re an ugly little creature,” the ogress said.  “You’re the boniest, skinniest thing I’ve seen.”  The ogress’s breath hit Odessa’s face like a sulfurous tropical wind; Odessa gagged and coughed as she tried to reply.  The ogress put Odessa back down and prodded her, sending her flying back into the entrance tunnel.  Odessa allowed her body to be carried by the force of the blow and when her feet made contact with the ground she dissipated the momentum with an agile safety roll back over her shoulder.

“I’m sorry!” the ogress exclaimed, “I didn’t mean to hurt you.  You’re not broken, are you?”

“That’s alright,” Odessa replied, dusting herself off.  “I’m used to being thrown around, it’s part of the act that I used to perform in.”

“You were in a show?  Could you show me more of your act?”

“I’d be happy to, but who were those two ogres who came by?”

“They were a couple of rock workers; I saw them come up here and wanted to see what they were up to.  Now come back here before they grab you and decide to have you as a snack.”

The ogress wore a skirt and a top made of animal skin; she had vast legs like gelatinous tree trunks and a pot belly that her top barely concealed.  Her skin was the colour of mustard and her limbs were roadmapped with protruding veins.  She had wiry hair that went just past her ears.  Having got over her astonishment at her sheer size and strangeness, Odessa examined the ogress’s face more appreciatively.  Her face had a couple of moles and what looked like a wart on the tip of her nose; her teeth, though large and yellow, were quite straight.  Her big flat nose seemed about right for her round face, and her pointy ears stuck out of her hair in a way that, if nothing else, suited her features.  Her narrow eyes examined Odessa intelligently.

“What are you, little things?” The ogress asked.

“My name is Odessa.  I’m a girl, or a woman I suppose.  What’s your name?”

“I am Turgolga, chieftain of the Roundbelly clan.”

“That sounds rather important.”

“Yes, we’re one of the leadings clans.  I’m also the head of the Council for Improvement and Creation,” Turgolga replied proudly.  “What’s that fuzzy thing you’ve got there?”

“His name is Trousers.  He’s a cat.”

“Praetorius Pathfinder, actually, but you may call me Trousers if you like.”

“It looks like something that one of our animals might cough up.  Come to think of it, one of the old ogresses told me she had seen a furball like that once.  She had never seen anything move so fast -- she chased it, but it escaped to the Outside, and of course the ogres there lost track of it within minutes.  You can’t rely on them to get anything right.  I always wondered what it looked like.  Quite unimpressive, I’ll say; and very skinny.  He’d barely be worth cooking by the looks of it.”

Odessa picked up Trousers and held him protectively.

“What are you doing here?” the Ogress asked.

“We’re travellers; we came here on a white bridge.  We need to find another one to continue our journey.”

“We’ve never had a traveller arrive by the Old Entrance.  There was a bridge that lead here once, but that was generations ago.”  Turgolga strode towards Odessa.  Odessa thought of running away, but she didn’t fancy her chances of making it past Turgolga’s large, powerful hands or faring any better with the ogres at the Old Entrance.  Turgolga picked Odessa up again and sniffed her suspiciously. “I’m not sure what magic brought you here, but you seem harmless enough.”  She put Odessa back down and put her hands on her enormous hips.

“Tell me, what’s the difference between a girl and a woman?”

“It’s hard to say,” Odessa began, “but some people would say that when you’re a woman you’re too soft and delicate to run around and climb trees and wrestle with boys and build things and break things, but when you’re a girl you’re tough enough to do all those things.”

“So does that mean you start as a woman and then grow into a girl?”

“Not exactly,” Odessa replied.  “It’s usually the other way around.”

“How do you start tough and become soft?  I’ve never heard of such a thing.”

Odessa was about to reply that she herself was still trying to work it out, when the heavy footsteps of the returning ogres interrupted them.

“Quick, come with me,” Turgolga whispered, “I’ll take you home; you’ll be safe there.  And besides, I’d love to show you to the Council.”

“Will they eat us?”

“Not unless we vote unanimously to do so,” Turgolga replied without a hint of sarcasm, “and besides they’ll probably enjoy your performance -- we always enjoy a new performance.  Also, I’d like to hear more about why your little people get soft when they grow up.”

As Turgolga set off, Odessa took a ball of bright string from her bag and let it trail out behind her.  They followed Turgolga into a dizzying labyrinth of tunnels, sometimes turning left, sometimes turning right, sometimes going straight ahead.  The walls of the tunnels were illuminated at regular intervals with crafted torches and decorated with delicate tribal patterns and artwork.

“These tunnels are incredible,” Odessa whispered.  “Who created all this?”

“We did, of course.”

“You mean the ogres?”

Turgolga snorted with laughter.  “What? No! Ogres can’t create anything -- except for some primitive patterns, I suppose.  Everything here was created by the ogresses.”

Odessa was confused.  “Those ogres who walked by looked enormously strong.  Why didn’t they help you?”

Turgolga made a guttural snort . “Clearly, you can’t tell the difference between creating and making.  The ogres did the stupid work of digging and carving and hewing and carrying, but you need ogresses to create the idea.  If you left an ogre to his own devices he’d simply bash his head against the rock, or rather bash another ogre’s head against the rock.  If it weren’t for the ogresses to keep the ogres in check, we’d all be huddled on the Entrance, shivering in the wind.”

“I think I understand,” Odessa replied.  “It must be difficult to live with ogres if they’re as rough and thick as that.  I guess they’re a bit like some boys where I come from.”

“We do our best to keep them in check,” Turgolga sighed, “But life for an ogress was never meant to be easy.”

Thank you! To answer your question about this line:
"With only a couple of slips, which the casual listener never notices anyway, Odessa finished the song with a delighted [should that be "delightful"] trill?"
What I wanted to convey is that Odessa took delight in finishing the song with a trill, i.e. "delighted". Odessa is not an accomplished pianist, so her judgement as to the use of the trill might not be perfect, but she really likes adding it when she can. entry.title: Chapter XIV: The Fall to Freedom
entry.content:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/lucianosignorelli/5288945940/sizes/l/
Tazagthrog stirred and sat up.  “What happened?”

Trousers looked up at Tazagthrog.  His skin glowed a gentle yellow in the moonlight and his amber eyes were now a delicate jasmine green.  “She reached out to you.  She wanted to share your pain.”

Tazagthrog’s face fell.

“I’m sorry,” he said.  “There was a lot of pain to share.”

He reached over and cupped Odessa’s body in his hands and held her over his lap.  He closed his eyes and filled the cave with a mournful groaning hum.  Trousers climbed up on to Tazagthrog and curled up on Odessa’s chest.

The melody of Tazagthrog's hums was broken by an angry shout.

“Tazagthrog! What are you doing! Have you gone completely out of your mind?”

He opened his eyes.  Turgolga emerged from the back of the cave and stared at him in astonishment.  Tazagthrog put Odessa and Trousers down and stood up to face her.  She gasped when she saw his exposed body, his bulging muscles, his electric blue scars, his jasmine green eyes.

“Tazagthrog, look at you!  Where are your scales?  Who did this to you?  You look ridiculous!  How are we supposed to go back home with you looking like this?  What will the Council think?”

Tazagthrog smiled and met her gaze.  Her slanted yellow eyes widened and her nostrils flared at the insult. 

Tazagthrog replied calmly, “Do  you remember that time in the square, Turgolga?  That time when I stepped into your space?”

She hesitated.  “All those years ago?  Yes, you nearly crashed into me; it was only sheer luck that I missed your ears when I hit you.  What’s that got to do with this?”

“I don’t think you wanted to hit my ears.”

She paused.  “Maybe I didn’t, so what then?  What are we going to do with you?  How could you do this to me?  Who ever heard of an ogre without scales?  And look at your eyes!  They’re like a  ogreson’s!  Did she do this to you?  I knew I should have squashed her the moment I saw her!”

Turgolga advanced on Odessa and Trousers, but Tazagthrog stepped in front of them.  “No, Turgolga, let them be.”

“What did you just say to me?”

Tazagthrog brought himself face to face with her.  “Leave them alone,” he said with gentle firmness.  “I’ll take them to the Outside: they can continue their journey from there.”

Turgolga’s hand struck his ear with especial venom.  He absorbed the blow as if he were made of rock.  Then, a growling hiss emanated from his throat as he reared up like a king cobra.  Turgolga raised her hand to strike him again.  As her open hand swung around, a much larger, more powerful hand lashed out at her cheek; she crashed to the ground and when she looked up, Tazagthrog’s scars danced on his heaving chest.

“How dare you?” She hissed.  “How dare you strike an ogress?”

“How dare you strike an ogre?” He replied.

Turgolga’s mouth moved but no words came out.  She looked at Odessa, who lay at the edge of the cave and Trousers who stood guard over her, his hazel eyes shining defiantly in the moonlight.

“It’s all because of her!” Turgolga shouted. “She’s worked some kind of magic on you.  You’re not the real Tazagthrog -- yes, that’s it -- you’ve been cursed by her, she’s robbed you of your scales!”

Turgolga heaved herself up and disappeared into the cave screaming and shouting for help.  Yugherkug emerged from the shadows.

“Father! What happened to you?  Where are your scales?”

“I'm free, Yugherkug.”

“How can that be?”

“I have learned what it means to allow someone to reach out to you.”

“How do you do that?  I want to get rid of my scales too.”

“Go to the place I told you about.  Learn to make more sketches, I left parchment and ink, drink and food for you, and then start journeying into the Great Beyond.”

“What lies in the Great Beyond?”

“I don't know, but you need to meet someone like Odessa, who can teach you the things we never learn here.”

“Can't you come with me?  I don't want to go alone.”

“It's too late for me, the others will be here soon and they will never let me leave now.”

Tazagthrog smiled at Yugherkug and extended his arms to him.  Yugherkug stepped forward; Tazagthrog hesitated slightly and then wrapped his arms around Yugherkug, who stiffened momentarily and then relaxed in his father's embrace.

“I'm sorry, Yugherkug.”

“Sorry for what?”

“I'm sorry I didn't stop your Cleansing.”

“If you had tried, you would have had to face the Council.”

“I know, but I still should have tried.”

They held each other silently.

“Goodbye, my son.”

“Goodbye, my father.”

I love you, my son.”

“What does 'love' mean, father?”

“It means being softer and tougher than ever before.  It means sharing something that no-one else can have, but it also means sometimes giving it up so that someone else can go on.”

“What are you going to give up for me?”

Turgolga returned with a crowd of astonished ogres and ogresses; Yugherkug faded back into the shadows as they approached.  Tazagthrog picked up Odessa and Trousers and held them to his chest.  When Yamizert pushed through the crowd she gasped.  She ran to her mother and clutched her hand.  Yugherkug stood in the shadows, entranced by his father’s pulsating scars and ran his hand along his own chest.

“Look at what that little monster did to my ogreman!” Turgolga declared.  “I invited her into my home, kept her as a pet, made sure that no ogre would lay his hands on her, and see how she has repaid me!”

The crowd murmured in astonishment:

- “Where are his scales?”
- “Are those the scars from his Cleansing?”
- “I’ve never seen an ogre without scales before.”
- “He’ll have to have another Cleansing.”
- “We can’t have an ogre walking around town without scales.”

“Tazagthrog has gone mad,” Turgolga declaimed.  “When I came up here he was in frenzied state; I tried to calm him, but he – he hit me!”

The crowd gasped

“It was all I could do to defend myself, luckily I escaped before he finished me off.  Look, look at these wounds!”

The crowd murmured excitedly as Turgolga pointed to the mild bruising on her face.

- “An ogre hitting an ogress?”
- “On purpose?”
- “Poor Tazagthrog has lost it.”
- “We need to set up the Cleansing immediately.”

“Tazagthrog,” Turgolga announced, “give me my pets back.  We need to dispose of these wicked creatures and prepare you for a Cleansing.  You’ve done a terrible thing, an unforgivable thing, but I can find it in my heart to forgive you if you grovel enough.”

The crowd advanced towards him.

“You don’t understand, Turgolga,” he replied.  “I’m not coming back.”

The crowd drew closer.

“Goodbye, Turgolga.  I always loved you.”

Tazagthrog cocooned Odessa and Trousers in his arms, closed his eyes, and allowed himself to fall backwards off the edge.

Tazagthrog's body glowed like a falling star as they made their long descent to the bottom of the canyon.  The night air rushed around him, but Odessa and Trousers were shielded from the wind.  As they fell, they were accompanied by the reflection of cats-eyes in the rock; time slowed down; it seemed they were in limbo.  Tazagthrog's hums vibrated through Trousers and Odessa; her eyes began to open.  The falling star completed its journey and found its resting place.  A mighty thud of bone and flesh on rock echoed around the canyon, but Odessa and Trousers were cushioned by his underbelly.  Tazagthrog's hands fell limply to his sides and he stared up into the sky.  His breathing was laboured.

Odessa woke up and looked around.  “Where are we?  What happened?”

“Turgolga found us.  She wanted to do away with us, but Tazagthrog saved us.  We’re at the bottom of the canyon.”

“How did we get down here?”

“Tazagthrog jumped, but he protected us from the fall.”

Odessa looked up at the cave far, far in the distance.

“Tazagthrog, are you alright?”

He tried to get up, but succeeded only in folding his hands on his chest.

“Oh, Tazagthrog, why did you do this to yourself to save us?  I’m so sorry I got you into all this trouble!”

He looked at her with a softness in his eyes.  His breathing became more laboured and the scars began to dim.

“No, Odessa, before I met you, I was nothing more than an ogre.  No-one ever reaches out to an ogre, no-one ever cares.  All my life I longed to be loved, but ogresses don’t allow themselves to love -- only to fear, only to hate -- and ogres aren’t allowed to be soft.  We live our whole lives in pain; we take it out on each other, on the animals we kill, on the rocks that we smash; but nothing has ever taken the pain away.”

“But all I did was open my heart to you, Tazagthrog.  Why can’t the ogresses do the same?”

“I don’t know.  Everyone says that after my Cleansing I was changed; but I think it was Turgolga who really changed.  I healed from the knife and the fire, but she was the one that delivered the knife and ignited the fire.  On the inside I’ve always been Tazagthrog the Gentle (that’s what they used to say to make fun of me), but something delicate inside Turgolga was burned away that day.  It took me years to understand this; and when I did, there was nothing anyone could do about it.”

He coughed painfully.

“I’m sorry, Tazagthrog, I’m so sorry for all of this.”

“Don’t apologise.  Without you, I would have never had the courage to tell Yugherkug about my sketches.  Now he knows what it means to be held and loved, and he shall see the things I never had the words to say.  One day, Yugherkug will find a way to tell other ogres what I never could.  You've given us a great gift, Odessa, the gift of a kind touch.  I am happy now, happier than I ever could have been...”

Tazagthrog closed his eyes with his hands on his heart.  A single large tear trickled down his cheek and crystallised into a pearl coloured orb that shone with a fading blue light, which rolled into Odessa’s hands.  The light of his scars faded completely.  He smiled as his breathing slowed and finally stopped.

Odessa laid her hand affectionately on Tazagthrog’s cheek, put the pearl into her backpack, and followed Trousers into the canyon.  After some time the canyon gave way to a ravine; the ravine to a beach; at the beach was a pier; at the end of the pier, Bridge #91 stretched out over the sea.

entry.title: Chapter V: Timotheos
entry.content:
Shortly after Trousers went exploring, Odessa was roused by a simple, haunting melody in A Minor that drifted across the grass.  She followed the music back to the piano, where a young man was playing.  His long blonde hair cascaded down his back in a shower of perfect ringlets and his red beard was neatly trimmed.  


Odessa tiptoed towards the piano and stood off to the side to watch.  On the ivory stage of the keyboard, his hands jetéd and glisséd with practised ease.  He inclined his head towards the heavens, almost as if he were about to kiss the air.  The music washed over Odessa; she felt tingles down her spine and goosebumps on her skin; her cheeks felt very warm and she found herself having to breathe deeply.  The sunlight draped over him like an ethereal cloak.


He guided the song to its conclusion and ended on two deep A notes.  He bowed his head until the last drop of sound evaporated on the wind.  His hands drifted down to his lap, he raised his head, and stared into the distance.  Odessa held her breath.  “What’s wrong with me, why can’t I go say Hello?” she thought to herself.


The young man turned to get up and started when he saw her.  He tilted his head slightly.  “Hello there,” he said.  Odessa’s throat felt dry.  “Ah, hello.  I heard you playing, and I just arrived, and I thought I would come to hear, I mean listen…” she drew a breath and exhaled.  “What I mean to say is you play beautifully.”


He glanced down momentarily, and looked up at her with twinkling blue eyes.  “Thank you,” he replied.  “It’s such a lovely day, I thought it a shame not to enjoy the piano for a bit.”


“Oh yes, it’s a gorgeous day!” Odessa blurted out.  She blushed.


The young man walked up to her and extended his hand.  He shook her hand with a firm, gentle grasp; as their hands parted, his fingertips brushed her palm and spurt of heat flashed across her hand.   “Thank you for listening to my tinkering.  I hope it wasn’t too clumsy.”  Odessa made to reply, but no sound came out of her mouth.


“What’s your name?”


“Odessa.”


“That’s a charming name.  It means traveller, right?”


“Yes, you could say I grew up on the road.  My parents are travelling merchants and entertainers.  What’s your name?”


“Timotheos,” he said with a touch of embarrassment.


“That’s a grand name.”


“Yes,” he laughed.  “I think I still have to grow into it.”


He held his hands out and she placed her hands in his.  He gazed at her fingers as his thumbs squeezed the back of her hands, and his fingertips brushed her palms.


“You must play the piano too, you have the hands for it.”


“Not nearly as well as you though, just a couple of bits and pieces.”


He looked up and grinned with a hint of shyness at her compliment; the sun lent his curls a golden glow.  A warm wave radiated from his hands into hers, along her arms, down into her chest.  A large dark cloud blotted out the sun and the clearing fell into darkness, except for the piano which radiated with a faintly blue white light.  


Timotheos took Odessa into an intimate closed hold: cheek to cheek, chest to chest, his right arm around her side, his right hand firmly between her shoulder blades, her right hand in his left.  The piano played a slow, dreamy waltz; the trees around the clearing hummed a deep bass accompaniment, and tapped their branches together to form a rustling drumbeat.


Timotheos and Odessa floated on the music around the piano.  
The stepped side to side, forward and back, swayed and turned, stopped and went.  Odessa didn’t know the steps but he lead her through an array of moves and movements with nothing but a light touch on her back, the flick of his wrist, the tips of his fingers, and the irresistible sway of his shoulders and hips.  She marvelled at the way they moved together.  She had never encountered this dance or heard this music, they contained familiar elements but combined them in strange new ways.  The music died down and the sun came back out.


They ended in a close embrace.  Odessa pressed her cheek against his; she didn’t want to let go.  His hands dropped to her waist; her hands sought out his shoulders.  “It’s a pleasure to meet you, Odessa,” he purred.  He smelled of almonds and spice and his warm breath made her ears tingle.  His beard felt like soft English grass.  His lips brushed her cheek and her fingers dug into his shoulders slightly.


“Maybe you can play something else for me?” She whispered hopefully.


He hummed a sigh; she breathed in deeply and his smell rushed to her head.  “One day,” he said sadly.  “One day, when I’m free.”  He cupped her cheek in his hand and inclined his head towards hers; the warmth of his breath reached out to her; their lips came within a hair’s breadth of each other.  He stopped, sighed, and pressed his forehead to hers.  He stepped back and guided her hands to the bottom of his ribcage.  “Think kind, happy thoughts,” he said.  Odessa thought of hugs and purrs, whispered words, gentle gestures, and stolen kisses.  An electric blue light appeared on his chest and outlined her fingers.  He pulled her hands away and cradled them in his; the palms of her hands were imbued with an ephemeral blue light.


“You have the gift of a kind touch, Odessa.  You have a great power to share another’s pain.  Please be careful: there is only so much suffering you can draw into yourself.”


He let go of her, turned around, and disappeared down the path without a sound.  Odessa watched him leave.  A great heaviness overcame her limbs and her head felt like a helium balloon.  She pressed her hair to her face; she could still smell almonds and spice.  Her feet came unstuck and she shook her head as if to wake up from a dwaal.


Odessa took off down the path after him.  It meandered through the garden, up the hills, through a maze (at the centre of which stood the statue of a cat on a brick wall), over a footbridge across a brook, until it ended at the edge of the floating island, where a Victorian street lamp now stood patiently in front of Bridge #135.  Timotheos stepped on to the bridge, turned to face her, closed his eyes and placed his hands over his heart.  A cloud drifted across the bridge and when it floated away, Timotheos was gone.


Trousers returned to find Odessa sitting with her legs crossed, her hands over her heart, staring at the clouds on the horizon.  Trousers stepped on to her lap and nuzzled her throat.  She wrapped her arms around him and kissed his head.

As Bridge #135 carried them down through the sky, the piano in the clearing played a sad, wistful tune.

entry.title: Chapter VI: The Cave in the Canyon
entry.content:
Chapter VI: The Cave in the Canyon


Bridge #135 took Odessa and Praetorius Pathfinder XII (known to his friends as Trousers) into the depths of a canyon.  They arrived at the opening of a great cave high up in the wall of the sheer cliff.
As they stepped off the final slat exploded in a rush and the rest of the bridge disintegrated and faded into the darkness.

In the morning sun, Odessa’s shadow stretched into the cave, but beyond the entrance it fell into darkness.  Odessa pulled out a flashlight from her bag.  It had been a birthday present from a strange old man who joined her family on their travels for a while.  When they set up their stalls and street performances, he walked around town chatting with people and somehow always convinced them to buy something or see a show.  He never rushed, yet he always got everything done.  He wore long flowing clothes and had a long white beard; he was the only adult Odessa knew he understood what her animals were saying.  On her birthday, he gave her the flashlight and promised her that as long as she looked with an open heart it would show her the way.

Trousers sniffed the air suspiciously.  “I don’t like the smell of this place,” he said.

The walls of the cave narrowed to a tall, broad tunnel.  There were animal bones and brown smears on the walls, and the sound of water dripping.  They reached a fork in the tunnel; Odessa stood there, wondering which way to go, when she heard lumbering footsteps and the sound of bodies dragging on the ground coming from the tunnel to her right.
She stepped into the tunnel to her left and the outline of a pair of giants came into view.  One dragged a collection of lifeless enormous sheep, goats, and cows behind him on a rope; the other carried a bundle of firewood under his arm.

“Let’s have a one of these as a snack at the Old Entrance.”  The first giant said in a deep, slow, almost childlike voice.
“Good idea, I’ve been bashing rock all through the night and I’m starvin’.”  Said his friend, in a slightly less deep, but equally uninflected tone.
“You ain’t starvin’, you fat oaf, you’re a greedy troll”
“Who you callin’ a troll, you goblin!”

And the two giants continued walking into the distance, exchanging clumsy insults and pushing each other into the wall, which sent vibrations through the rock.


“Trousers, what were those men?  I’ve never seen anyone so big in my life!”

“We are in the ogres’ lair.  My grandfather, Praetorius Pathfinder X (Known to his friends as Buttons for the dots on his belly) passed through here once.  He said the ogres are very stupid, but if they get a hold of you, they think it good sport to use you as a plaything -- and they play very rough indeed.  He also said to beware of -- watch out!”

And before Odessa could turn around, a pair of huge hands reached out of the shadows, grabbed her by the waist and lifted her high into the air.  Odessa’s vision was filled by a pair of huge yellow eyes and big yellow teeth.

“You’re an ugly little creature,” the ogress said.  “You’re the boniest, skinniest thing I’ve seen.”  The ogress’s breath hit Odessa’s face like a sulfurous tropical wind; Odessa gagged and coughed as she tried to reply.  The ogress put Odessa back down and prodded her, sending her flying back into the entrance tunnel.

“I’m sorry!” the ogress exclaimed, “I didn’t mean to hurt you.  Are you broken?”

“That’s alright,” Odessa replied, picking herself up.  “Who were those two ogres who came by?”

“They were a couple of rock workers; I saw them come up here and wanted to see what they were up to.  Now come back here before they grab you and decide to have you as a snack.”

The ogress wore a skirt and a top made of animal skin; she had vast legs like gelatinous tree trunks and a pot belly that her top barely concealedl.  Her skin was the colour of mustard and her limbs were roadmapped with protruding veins.  She had wiry hair that went just past her ears.  Having got over their astonishment at her sheer size and strangeness, Odessa examined the ogress’s face more appreciatively.  Her face had a couple of moles and what looked like a wart on the tip of her nose, and her teeth, though large and yellow, were quite straight.  Her big flat nose seemed about right for her round face, and her pointy ears stuck out of hair in a way that, if nothing else, suited her features.  Her almond shaped eyes examined Odessa intelligently.

“What are you, little things?” The ogress asked.

“My name is Odessa.  I’m a girl, or a woman I suppose.  What’s your name?”

“I am Turgolga, chieftain of the Roundbelly clan.”

“That sounds rather important.”

“Yes, we’re one of the leadings clans.  I’m also the head of the Council for Improvement and Creation,” Turgolga replied proudly.  “What’s that furry thing you’ve got there?”

“This is Trousers.  He’s a cat.”

“It looks like something that one of our animals might cough up.  Come to think of it, one of the old ogresses told me she had seen a furball like that once.  She had never seen anything move so fast -- she chased it, but it escaped to the Outside, and of course the ogres there lost track of it within minutes.  I always wondered what it looked like.  Quite unimpressive, I’ll say; and very skinny.  He’d barely be worth cooking by the looks of it.”

Odessa picked up Trousers and held him protectively.

“What are you doing here?”

“We’re travellers; we came here on a white bridge.  We need to find another one to continue our journey.”

“We’ve never had a traveller arrive by the Old Entrance.  There was a bridge that lead here once, but that was many years ago.”  Turgolga picked Odessa up again and sniffed her suspiciously. “I’m not sure what magic brought you here, but you seem harmless enough.”  She put Odessa back down and put her hands on her enormous hips.

“Tell me, what’s the difference between a girl and a woman?”

“It’s hard to say,” Odessa began, “but some people would say that when you’re a woman you’re too soft and delicate to run around and climb trees and wrestle with boys and build things and break things, but when you’re a girl you can do all those things.”

“So does that mean you start as a woman and then grow into a girl?”

“Not exactly,” Odessa replied.  “It’s usually the other way around.”

“How do you start tough and become soft?  I’ve never heard of such a thing.”

Odessa was about to reply that she herself was still trying to work it out, when the heavy footsteps of the returning ogres interrupted them.

“Quick, come with me,” Turgolga whispered, “I’ll take you home; you’ll be safe there.  And besides, I’d love to show you to the Council.”

“Will they eat us?”

“Not unless we vote unanimously to do so,” Turgolga replied without a hint of sarcasm.

As Turgolga set off, Odessa surreptitiously took a ball of bright string from her bag and let it trail out behind her.  They followed Turgolga into a dizzying labyrinth of tunnels, sometimes turning left, sometimes turning right, sometimes going straight ahead.  The walls of the tunnels were illuminated at regular intervals with crafted torches and decorated with delicate tribal patterns and artwork.

“These tunnels are incredible,” Odessa whispered.  “Who created all this?”

“We did, of course.”

“You mean the ogres?”

Turgolga snorted with laughter.  “What? No! Ogres can’t create anything -- except for some primitive patterns, I suppose.  Everything here was created by the ogresses.”

Odessa was confused.  “But those ogres who walked by looked enormously strong.  Why didn’t they help you?”

Turgolga sighed. (Although it sounded like a guttural snort)  “Clearly, you can’t tell the difference between creating and making.  The ogres did the stupid work of digging and carving, but you need ogresses to create the idea of doing so.  If you left an ogre to his own devices he’d simply bash his head against the rock, or rather bash another ogre’s head against the rock.  If it weren’t for the ogresses to keep the ogres in check, we’d all be huddled on the Entrance, shivering in the wind.”

“I think I understand,” Odessa replied.  “It must be difficult to live with ogres if they’re as rough and thick as that.”

“We do our best to keep them in check,” Turgolga sighed, “But life for an ogress was never meant to be easy.”
