entry.title: Chapter I: Climbing the Mountain
entry.content:
Image from doppingqnk on http://deviantart.net/
Bridge #90 ended on a small cliff edge on the side of a mountain, illuminated by a lonely Victorian street lamp.  As Odessa and Praetorious Pathfinder XII (known to his friends as Trousers) hopped off, the final slat burst into flames and fizzled away into the abyss.  A cold wind moaned.

"This rock feels strange under my paws," Trousers said.

Odessa knelt down; it felt warm and rubbery; she tried to recall what it reminded her of, but her mind went blank.

She stood up facing the mountain.  A narrow path wound around the corner to their left.

From the depths of the mountain an amused chuckle boomed through the rock.  "What makes you think that you can ascend me, you little specks?"

Trousers leapt into Odessa's arms, his hackles raised.

"Come," the mountain said sternly and a large hole opened up in front of them, "don't scamper about until I fling you into the abyss.  I've been expecting you."

Odessa smelled cinnamon-laced baking.  She took a step towards the opening, which was about the size a large window, just above her head.

"That's it, my little ones," the mountain whispered, "we've got everything you'll need."

Trousers tensed.  "Something about this makes my whiskers twitch," he said, "we ought to move on from here."

Odessa stopped.  "Thank you for your kind offer, Mr Mountain," she began, "but we can't stay.  We -- "

"What! How dare you?!" the mountain bellowed, "No-one can refuse me!  Get in there this instant!"

A blast of icy wind blew in from the abyss; Odessa felt herself being thrown off balance towards the opening.  She got down on all fours and crawled towards the wall.  A set of long, stick-like arms sprang out, writhing like a spider's legs, snatching wildly at the air above her head.  The arms and hands were deathly white, with long, red, sharp fingernails.  Odessa couldn't smell the warm cinnamon anymore; instead, a faint stench of gore.

A low, wordless moan poured out of the opening, and with every passing second another voice was added to its chorus.  Before long, it sounded as if the whole mountain was crying and shouting and hissing and rasping in the screaming wind.

Odessa crawled along the wall towards the path, the wind barraging her face, until she turned the corner and got out of the wind.  The voices died down and the opening snapped shut, yanking in the writhing hands.

Odessa collapsed on to her back and lay gasping for a while.  Trousers emerged from her jacket and looked around timidly.  He sat down on her chest, sank his chin, and licked the front of his chest vigorously.  She looked up at him but he averted his gaze.  She reached out and stroked him reassuringly.  He stopped his grooming and lay down with his front paws near the base of her throat.

"Thank you for warning me," she said.

He mumbled a bashful reply and purred into her chest.

After some time, they followed the winding path up the mountain.

The mountain teemed with sunken faces and curious eyes; all along the way they were followed by moans and hisses and unintelligible whispers.  Grasping hands slithered from crevices in the wall and sprouted from the ground underfoot.  After one red-taloned hand nearly latched on to his tail, Odessa ignored Trousers' protests and plonked him in her bag, to keep an eye on her belongings, of course.

The path ended at a crater with walls the height of Odessa's head.  In front of them was a narrow opening in the wall, just wide enough for Odessa to squeeze through.

A face took shape in the wall near the gate and called out to them:

"Pssst, don't go any further!"

"Why not?"

"That's where the Man in the Mountain lives."

"He's just the man we've been looking for."

"No, you don't understand!" he exclaimed and his eyes flitted back and forth, as if to check that the coast was clear.  "It’s perfect in there.  Once you're in, you'll never leave!"

"I don't understand," Odessa replied.  "Wouldn't that be a wonderful thing?"

The face contorted in disagreement.

"The clever people around me always said we should live in a world where everyone is equal and everyone is taken care of.  I never questioned it.  I always thought it unfair that some people are beautiful, some are rich, some are clever, some are strong; some have a good life, some have a hard life.  So I came here with my friends because we heard that everyone is equal and everyone is taken care of here."

"And is it?"

"Yes! Can't you see?  He's given us everything we asked for!"

All along the wall faces emerged like blisters on burned skin.  They were not identical, but from a distance they all had the same sunken lifeless eyes, the same grey skin, the same sharp teeth, the same miserable expression.

"What are you talking about, Comrade?" a nearby face asked, "have you started talking about life outside the mountain again?  Do you want everybody to just die in the middle of the street?"

"No, that's not what I'm saying at all!" Comrade said.  "I'm saying that we all got what we asked for, but it's not what we thought it would be."

"You need to grow up and accept that life here is as good as it could be," another face said.

"We have coffee and cake here!"

"I don't even like coffee and cake," Comrade replied.

"Just because you don't like it doesn't mean we can't have our coffee and cake," another voice jumped in.

"That's not what I'm saying at all," Comrade retorted, "What I'm trying to say is --"

"I'm offended by that!" said another voice.

"Me too!"

"So am I!"

"Yes, I'm offended as well!"

An army of long arms with red-taloned hands slithered from the wall and pulled him out of the wall up to his waist.  They swarmed his body, latching on to every of piece of him.  Comrade started to scream but was cut short as the hands ripped him apart and directed chunks of his flesh and bone towards the salivating, razor-toothed faces around him.  Before long, there was nothing left of Comrade except for a bloody stump in the wall, which suddenly swallowed his remains and closed itself, leaving a perfectly smooth section where he used to be.

The other faces chomped noisily for a bit and then sank into the wall.
Odessa looked for another way to leave the mountain, but her only option was the opening in the wall.  With her heart in her mouth, she tip-toed towards it and squeezed through.
